39473515.review:
[h1]จากความสนุกของการแฮคเกม นำไปสู่ความไม่สนุกของการแฮคเกม!?[/h1]

.hack//G.U. เป็นภาคต่อจากเกมซีรีส์ .hack ซึ่งทั้ง 2 ภาคหลักนี้เคยลงให้กับ PS2 มาแล้ว ผู้เล่นที่ไม่เคยเล่น .hack ภาคแรกมาก่อนก็สามารถเล่น .hack//G.U. ได้ แต่ผมแนะนำว่าหากเข้าเกมแล้ว ให้เข้าไปดูข้อมูลใน Terminal Disc ก่อน เพื่อที่จะได้รู้เรื่องราวความเป็นมา และจะได้เพิ่มอรรถรสในการเล่นเกมภาคนี้ครับ


โดยเกมนี้ เราจะรับบทเป็นผู้เล่นคนนึงที่เป็นผู้เล่นเกม MMORPG ที่ชื่อว่า The World R:2 โดยใช้ชื่อในเกมว่า Haseo ซึ่งเริ่มเกมมาเราจะเป็นผู้เล่นหน้าใหม่ที่ไม่เคยเล่นเกมนี้มาก่อน แต่โชคดีที่เราเจอผู้เล่นรุ่นพี่ใจดี สอนให้เข้าใจถึงวิธีการเล่นเบื้องต้น สอนการต่อสู้ให้ สอนการเคลียร์เงื่อนไขของแต่ละดันเจียน แต่พอเคลียร์ดันเจียนได้ รุ่นพี่ก็เผยธาตุแท้ออกมาว่าเป็น PK (Player Killer) ซะงั้น ทำให้ Haseo ถูกซัดลงไปหมอบกับพื้น แต่ก็ได้รับความช่วยเหลือจากผู้เล่นปริศนา
หลังจากเหตุการณ์ที่ถูก PK ในวันแรกผ่านไป 8 เดือน ชื่อของ Haseo ก็กลายเป็นที่รู้จักกันว่าเป็น PKK (Player Killer Killer) อันดับต้นๆของเกม ตัวละครของเราแข็งแกร่งขึ้นมากจนได้รับฉายาว่า Terror of Death ซึ่งตอนนี้เรากำลังติดตามล่าตัว PK ที่ชื่อ Tri-Edge เพราะว่า Tri-Edge เคย PK เพื่อนสาวในเกมที่ชื่อ Shino ไป แต่ว่า ในชีวิตจริงเพื่อนสาวคนนี้ก็มีอาการโคม่าด้วย ทำให้เราต้องหาว่าแท้ที่จริงแล้ว Tri-Edge ทำอย่างไรถึงได้ PK ตัวละครในเกมแล้วมีผลกับชีวิตจริง หลังจากการติดตามหาข้อมูล Tri-Edge มานานหลายเดือน ในที่สุด Haseo ก็ได้เผชิญหน้ากับ Tri-Edge ซึ่ง Haseo ก็ไม่รอช้าที่จะเข้าไปจัดการ Tri-Edge ด้วยกำลังทั้งหมด แต่ไม่ว่า Haseo จะใช้ความสามารถแค่ไหน ก็ไม่สามารถแตะต้อง Tri-Edge ได้แม้แต่น้อย แถมยังถูก Tri-Edge ยิงพลังประหลาดจัดการได้อย่างง่ายดาย จากที่จะมาล้างแค้นกลายเป็นถูกย้ำแค้นซะงั้น
เมื่อรู้ตัวอีกที ตัวละคร Haseo ของเราก็ถูกรีเซ้ตเลเวลจาก 133 กลายเป็นเลเวล 1 แถมค่าสถานะ สกิลต่างๆ แม้กระทั้งไอเทมก็หายไปหมด การเดินทางเพื่อสืบหาความจริงและการแก้แค้นอีกครั้งจึงได้เริ่มขึ้น

[b]Pros.[/b]
- เกมถูกรีมาสเตอร์ใหม่จาก PS2 มาเป็น 1080p ที่ 60fps ได้อย่างสวยงาม
- การพอร์ทเกมทำได้อย่างลื่นไหล ไม่มีบัคมากวนใจเหมือนเกมที่พอร์ทจากเครื่องคอนโซลเกมอื่นๆ
- ดันเจียนที่ใช้การผสมคำภาษาอังกฤษ 3 คำขึ้นมา ทำให้เกิดสภาพแวดล้อม ศัตรู และความยากที่หลากหลาย สามารถเก็บเลเวลได้สนุกขึ้น
- มีการแลกเปลี่ยนไอเทมกับผู้เล่นอื่นๆ และเราสามารถที่จะให้ของขวัญกับผู้เล่นอื่นๆ เมื่อความสัมพันธ์เพิ่มขึ้น เราก็สามารถเชิญผู้เล่นคนอื่นมาร่วมปาร์ตี้ได้ด้วย
- ตัวเกมมีการปรับสมดุลย์ใหม่ ไม่ว่าจะเป็นการเพิ่มความจุของไอเทมจากเดิมที่ 50 มาเป็น 99 ต่อชิ้น, ปรับให้เดินไวขึ้น, เพิ่ม cheat mode สำหรับผู้เล่นที่อยากเสพเนื้อเรื่อง
- เนื้อเรื่องในเกมมีความน่าสนใจ ไม่ว่าจะเป็นดราม่า หักหลัง รักๆใคร่ๆ ในเกมใส่มาจนครบ
- เพิ่มเนื้อหาตอนที่ 4 ที่ต้นฉบับของ PS2 ไม่มี!!!
- เพิ่มฟอร์มใหม่, อาวุธใหม่, ดันเจียนใหม่ๆที่สมัย PS2 ไม่มี!!!
- desktop ก่อนเข้าเกมถูกวาด background ขึ้นมาใหม่ ให้มีความสวยงามมากขึ้น

[b]Cons.[/b]
- เสียงสนทนาของตัวละคร ที่ยังไม่ชวนให้ฟังเหมือนตอนเล่นบน PS2
- เล่นกับจอย DS4 โดยตรงไม่ได้ ต้องลง mod เพื่อเล่นกับ xinput แทน

[b]Verdict: 9/10[/b]

39446818.review:
I played the .hack games back when they were first released on the PS2. I bought this collection as soon as I heard about it and I don't regret it all. The combat in this game is a bit simple with a single attack button and the abillity to map four special skills at any time but it works and well it's not the greatest combat system ever, can even be enjoyable. The graphics have really been stepped in this collection from the originals and are great to look at. 

The setting is easily the best part this game has going for it. It does everything in it's power to make it feel like you are actually playing a real MMO. From a desktop that includes news articles, forum boards (where NPCs you'll see in The World, help each other, troll each other and share art much like a real fandom) to a side game and emails. 

This is a very cut scene heavy game and they can be lengthy at times, as well as awkward (lips don't move in a lot of cutscenes for at least the first three games, I can't comment on Recode yet) so be aware of that. The characters are varried and intersting enough to be invested in and range from simple players in the game to people who work behind the scenes to protect to Graphic deisgners chasing after people who deface the game.

Liked .hack series from the first it came and I hope there will be pc version of the first four or at least .hack//link.

Only bad thing about .hack//G.U is that it is very easy with exception of one or two bosses.

39402978.review:
In my time gaming on PC, which has been for over 15 years - I've played a lot of remakes/remasters. 

This has to be hands down the one I've been most excited for. 
Like many I've been skeptical after so many have been so bad, and like many I would have hoped for the original series more than this.

HOWEVER, I have to say I'm truly happy with my purchase.

Graphically this game looks amazing. This game aged like fine wine. It looks and plays incredibly well. 9/10

Story wise, this game was always very deep and intriguing. If you have or haven't played you're still going to be wow'd. 8/10

Voice acting is about what you would expect from the era, but for the time it was pretty damn good. As there isn't live conversations and instead audio clips blended, it can cause a slight distraction or loss of feeling but overall still pretty great. 6/10

Gameplay still holds up. Yes, it's a bit PS2, but we're accounting for it being a PS2 game. 8/10

PLAYABILITY. This is an important one. A lot of remasters/remakes are riddled with bugs or frame rate caps. As of right now, I'm getting between 60-144fps steady. Depends on whether I'm in game or in cutscene. It all blends well, and there have been minor bugs that aren't stopping me from playing. Most notably is where the game says I'm getting 144fps but it feels like time slowed down and I'm getting 10. I'm not sure the cause as I haven't looked into it, and I haven't looked for a fix although I'm sure there is one.    7/10

CONTROLS. Another big one. Using Big Picture and a steam controller, the controls are very straight forward and are even labeled in game for the steam controller as it seems that's what they had in mind. It makes playing it very simple, and very fun. FOR CONTROLLER 10/10
For keyboard however, the controls are odd off the bat and there wasn't any detection whether or not I was using a controller. It kept saying "Hit X" "Hit B". This really bothers me. You can however change and view controls while NOT in game, during the title selection menu. FOR KEYBOARD: 5/10

IN GAME OPTIONS are none existant and it really bothers me. You can change everything while you are in the title selection screen, but sometimes I'd like to at least be able to change volume levels as it can be a bit obnoxious at times. There really is no reason to not include this, and unfortunately as they are vitually nonexistant... 2/10.


Overall, if you're a fan of the series or even just interested in it, I HIGHLY recommend this as it's a fantastic series, and a really well done remake.

39379884.review:
It's so good to have this game brought onto Steam.
I played the original 1~3 on the PS2 as they came out, and boy this game aged very, very well.
The combat doesn't feel outdated, and it's just as fun as I remember it being.

It's very much a "game of it's time" as there are a lot more cutscenes, and story than games of today.
There are also the situation and dialogue that are "of it's time", and to people who have never played any JRPGs in their lives will find that this game seems very "anime" in a lot of their character mannerisms. 

All in all, it's a great game series, and I would highly recommend it.
Though, you might wanna end task > touch keyboard. before starting, as that will make the game crash on PCs.
But it's easy to avoid, and is still worth purchasing and playing.
The story is very great, and focuses heavily on character development (and not just Haseo's either!)

I've yet to play the fourth game, as the data carries through games 1 -> 2 -> 3 ->4
So why start out with a nubbie baseline Haseo in 4, when I can be OP Haseo who started from game 1?
gg

39374216.review: .hack gu last recode is a good collection that fixes most of the problems i had with ps2 versions like improving the growth of skill levels, better frame rate, etc. But some of the side quests are still annoying like Bikman's in volume 1 and the book of 1000 which can take up 2/3rds of your main story playtime to complete (for me it was 19 hours in volume 1 when i beat the game then i had 28 for 100%). there should have been multiple items added in the game to tell you what you were missing in an area like volume 2 or 3 but for weapons, armor, and consumables. I would have also hoped that they would fix the long pauses in cutscenes to make the conversations flow much more smoothly. the terminal discs are great but it can be almost essential to understand the backstory of the events in volume 1. Most newcomers to the series are probably going to jump right into volume 1 and not understand what is going on and if they want to understand they are going to have to watch about 45 minutes of cutscene just on terminal discs then watch 20 minutes of the opening of gu. Even after they watch the first 4 or 5 terminals that are unlocked you have to spend about another hour watching the rest as players beat each game to get the full experience. Volume 4 in all honesty feels like fanfiction that feels like it was added to sell more copies to older fans which this collection was made for them in mind. :SPOILERS: Volume 4 could have been much better if the events happend much earlier like a few months before The World went offline. With that time it could develop what haseo had to do to get his 5th form and how AIDA still exists. As it stands now the game should have been called Volume 3 epilouge. Don't get me wrong i love the .hack series and I have been waiting for something like this for years, but starting with GU was probably not the best for newcomers. If they started out with the 4 original games then it wouldn't have been as confusing since you need no backstory to enjoy those games to the fullest. At this point im just rambling, so if you want to start getting into the .hack series with this collection look up a plot analysis of .hack roots the anime of gu that show the events before gu (optional look up a wiki about the first 4 games). Hopefully this review helps necomers considering the .hack series and old time fans wanting to experience GU again.

39153556.review:
Onze années, il aura fallu attendre onze ans pour que nous, joueurs européens, puissions jouer aux jeux G.U.. L'attente fut longue, mais quel plaisir de pouvoir enfin y jouer.

Avant de se frotter à G.U., que ce soit les jeux, le film ou le manga, il est conseillé de voir l'animé .hack//Roots, histoire de ne pas être perdu. J'ai aimé faire ces jeux, mais même en gros fan que je suis, je ne peux pas nier les défauts du titre. Bon le volume 4 est un cas particulier vu qu'il est sorti en 2017 pour les 15 ans de la saga Dot hack (. hack//) donc je vais le traiter à part.

Pour les volumes 1 à 3, ce sont des jeux qui datent de 2006-2007 donc certaines mécaniques sont datés, sans parler des animations. De plus, un gros défaut étant qu'à chaque jeu, le scénario nous fait passer systématiquement par l'arène. Même si dans certains cas l'idée est bonne, je trouve regrettable que ce soit un passage obligé à chaque volume. Ça accentue le côté redondant du titre.

Parlant redondance, ici, les zones sont soit un champ (tuer le boss ou ouvrir le temple), soit un dongeon (trouver le trésor). Une bonne variation par rapport à la première quadrilogie où il fallait explorer un champ pour trouver et faire le dongeon. Par contre, il est dommage qu'il y ait si peu de décors différents pour les zones. Au bout d'un moment, à voir les mêmes décors, c'est un peu ennuyeux tout de même.

Autre faiblesse, les quêtes. D'un volume à l'autre, on se retrouve à faire certains quêtes identiques; notamment Bikman, le Mecha Grunty, les chims et les animaux porte-bonheur. Bon les PK c'est sympa. Mais c'est vraiment les mêmes, à refaire à zéro, sans prendre en compte qu'on l'a déjà fait dans le(s) volume(s) précédent(s).  En soit, elles permettent de gagner des objets (différents à chaque volume) et un succès mais elles n'ont pas beaucoup d'intérêt.

Je ne vais pas entrer dans le détail, mais dommage que l'Avatar ne soit pas plus utilisé que ça, au moins utilisé différemment. On aurait pu avoir des passages à la Zone of the Enders, dommage de s'être imité à une utilisation.
Un truc qui m'a pas mal frustré, c'est de ne pas pouvoir monter sa guilde au niveau 10 pour avoir le droit à sa propre zone personnelle. Même la gestion de la guilde n'est pas très développée, c'est dommage. on se contente de la faire monter de niveau jusqu'à 9.
Sans oublier la faible difficulté des jeux, car avoir 4-5 niveaux d'avance et on peut tracer les yeux fermés. La traduction française est parfois un peu aux fraises, et le jeu rame par moment, mais de fou. 

Malgré ces défauts, le plaisir d'y jouer est là. Il y a de gros défauts, mais d'excellentes qualités aussi.

Le point fort principal est le fond, ce que ça raconte. C'est énorme, c'est juste génial. Même si certaines idées ne sont pas assez exploitée jusqu'au bout (comme le tournoi du volume 3). Mais voir les événements en jeu et les répercussions "irl" via les news, et les forums, c'est grisant. Je ne vais pas développer ces points mais c'est du bon, ça fait plaisir. Il y a vraiment de très bonnes idées.
Les jeux datent de 2006, mais face à plusieurs articles lu en cours de partie, je me suis demandé si déjà à l'époque c'était d'actualité. Certains de ces articles semblent d'actualité aujourd'hui, mais à l'époque, je n'ai pas souvenir, ou alors c'était moins relayé.

Autre petit truc plaisant, l'évolution de son personnage. Alors une évolution psychologique, ce qui est normal mais aussi d'apparence. À chaque évolution, dû à une extension de classe, l'apparence change et nous donne accès à une arme supplémentaire (glaive, faux,..) et c'est plutôt cool à jouer, on peut ainsi switcher en cours de combat entre différentes armes. Une petite chose parmi d'autres qui font plaisir.

Alors le volume 4, cas particulier. C'est un épilogue qui se torche en quelques heures seulement, surtout si on a bien poussé le volume précédent et que l'on commence level max. En plus, la plupart des fonctionnalités ne sont pas disponibles donc ça donne un aspect ligne droite pour terminer. Par contre, rien que pour l'épée et ses capacités, ça vaut le détour. ^^

Petit bonus, le mode parodie qui détournent certains passages du jeu. Il y en a des drôles.

Dans l'ensemble, très bon jeux, riches dans le fond, mais la forme pêche un peu, classique avec cette saga. Je suis heureux d'avoir pu les faire. Maintenant, j'espère de nouvelles productions pour cette saga, en gardant un fond riche et en s'inspirant du p'tit nouvau sao pour la forme; mais n'oublions pas que Tron (1982) était là avant.

38921977.review:
[h1]If you're a .Hack//G.U. fan from a decade ago, get this.[/h1]

This game is meant for those who want the nostalgia of playing through this series again. If you're new you probably will not have as good of a time unless you are already into .Hack//, so [b]please take that into very serious consideration[/b]. Personally I have to admit I am a MASSIVE .Hack// fan, I even brought out the physical game guides from over a decade ago when I bought this game (yes, I kept them for a decade). To say my positive review might be biased is about an obvious of a statement as "water is wet".

Just as a heads up though, the fourth volume is more of an epilogue than another volume! Even still, I had a lot of fun with it and it made me very happy. I can't say any more without spoiling things, but if you played volumes 1 to 3, play volume 4. Also the Doppelganger armor and trinket from vol3 as well as the demon shoes are still insanely OP, get them. If you're willing to brave the Forest of Pain, make sure you get Indulgence as well. You literally become an unstoppable killing machine.
If you aren't willing to go back through the volumes, that's OK too! They have a cheat option available to you that gives you everything you need to have fun again. (also worth noting is the BIG experience boost from the PS2 version regardless of cheat mode or regular mode, it saves a LOT of time)

There are also VERY strong hints that The World R:3 will be a thing, so prepare yourselves for a new series in the somewhat distant future. Even Piros the Third mentions it (and he's voiced by the president of the company who make these games!).

Having played the origonal triligy on the ps2, I remember waiting at the end of each game for the next one to be released. I would play through them again each time the next came out before going onto the new one. This being directly after playing the origonal saga. 

I say this because upon playing through the story and feeling the emotions of my younger self I can say these games and their story stands up to the test of time. It is still a great story and I even remember all the nods and hints to the origonal four games. 

Reconnection being the new volume added to the series making G.U. now a saga as well there is a better feeling of closure than there was before, though bittersweet it may be. 

I recommend this package deal to all long time fans of the .hack series and fans of JRPGs that have yet to play them. All but the last game have so much to do during and after the story that you could play one single game for 100s of hours and it could still be fun. I binge played these four games in a matter of three days spending about 20 hours per game to do their story and extras for Vol. 1-3 and then spend about 5 hours for Reconnetion.

Still fun, still great story, lots to do, worth every penny

38671740.review:
First time I played this long ago on PS2 and it was amazing. I loved .hack anime series and being able to play it as the game were just amazing. I wouldn't call it amazing by modern standards, but back then I didn't know better, I guess.

To be honest today it looks kind of bland and still unpolished. The story is great as always, but the presentation is riddled with things which wold be better left back there in the past like absurdly annoying quests which you have to do 3 times each because the game divided in 3 volumes. Yes, I do understand that the game were released in 3 volumes back there due to DVD size limitations, but do we really need these volumes today on the PC? Well, they did make it easier to grind these levels now, and they added option to replay the battle if you loose, which really helps once or twice in the second and third volumes when you accidentally encounter chaotic PK in the low-level location, but these changes turned volume 1 into a massive joke since you end up overleveled all the time. The balance kicks in only closer to the end of volume 2 and never on the arena. Every time I came to the arena I were 10+ levels above which means instant win. Not like I'd lose if the enemy would be 5-8 levels ahead, but no challenge at all? Seriously? That's just boring. Well, I can continue like that for a while.

Also, back then I thought it gives somewhat accurate representation of MMORPG games (minus the crazy stuff), but honestly if you somehow haven't played MMOs yet then don't take this as a reference. MMOs are inherently unfair. ;) However, it still have a great atmosphere with that virtual in-game forum and news site and that's what's important in the Role Playing Game. You actually feel like you live in that world.

Anyway, I DO recommend this game because even with all the downsides and weaknesses of an 11 years old game it's still great. Just don't expect fancy graphics. They did improve it a bit since PS2, but pretty much everything besides the main characters lacks details. Well, this is not a re-make after all, so I haven't expected anything, but HD textures and better models for the main characters and GUI anyway, which they did.

Now, about volume 4. It isn't really a new chapter in the story, however it addresses a few loose ends in it and grants main character another job extension which breaks ugly-nice-fugly-nice pattern from the original 3 volumes and also nice looking and fun to play with at least for the duration of this volume. Which is really short. Well, maybe because there are nothing, but the main story anyway and you just can't walk around and do nothing, grind or meddle with that Crimson VS idle card game, or... anything else. And even half of that consists of talking to all the characters again... and again. Because Haseo just can't go straight to the point, he had to talk to everyone before going anywhere, right? Heh. So, yes, it isn't a new chapter in the story. It's the love letter to all the fans which played the game for all these years. It's the epilogue and honestly it's a good one, so I don't complying. The story were great on its own and with an epilogue it's even better now. Just when given a choice stick to the first option...

38641494.review:
"I told people online about my problems. In real life, no one would care about them, but online, everyone cares. My online friends are all so nice. They worry about me, they give me advice. I just wish real life was like my life online." -Quote from an article in the game DAMN.

.Hack//G.U. has a great narrative that give reason to invest time in the game. There is more than enough cutscenes to entertain the story and develop the characters. Furthermore, the fictional forums the game provides in its internet sphere offers branching narratives and lore to the world of .Hack in game and the real world. The game was ahead of its time tackling issues relevant today about technology when it becomes too much a part of our lives not just for a solution but more so for convenience (which you would have to read in the in game forum). It also makes you feel like you are in a forum with people discussing these topics like in real people. But even if you don't read them, the narrative will allude to these things or some characters will mention them.

This series was a crazy ride from start to finish. The story was amazing with a lot of feels and unexpected twists. It starts off a little slow but quickly starts to pick up as Haseo, the main character starts to learn more and more about whats going on in "The World" and what he has to do to meet his own goals. Most of the characters Haseo meets are very likable and you get to see them grow throughout the whole series and also help Haseo grow into a better character himself. Everytime you get a new party member you add them to your friends list like you would in an actual MMO style game which lets you invite them into your party for the story, quests, dungeons, etc. You also get the ability to trade with them and give them gifts while in a party. The game does a really good job of making you feel immersed into "The World" with how it has you logging out to a desktop and back into the game as if you're the one actually playing it and having a friends list full of the characters you meet throughout the story.

The combat is pretty straightforward and simple with a one button attack but you get additional skills to execute. Additionally, you also have recovery attacks for more strategy if I may say so. It doesn't sound fun from words alone but it is when you have your hands in control of the game. Gameplay allows you to do general things you'd expect from an actual mmo like guild management, arena, improve gears questing etc.. The game isn't complex by any means. It's straightforward fun as a game should be.

Oh! And music! Music in this game is just fascinating. I even can't say anything else about it.

Overall I would definitely recommend anyone that loves RPGS and MMOs to play this amazing series because it was truly a great experience.

38638528.review:
.hack//GU is a game that takes place between and after the anime series .hack//Roots, It is also linked to the first 4 games released on the PS2 back in 2002. This is a treat for fans and for newcomers to the series as it expands past the 3rd disk. You get all three games bundled opposed to buying them all seperately. 

The Graphics are pretty dated but slightly enhanced for the HD remake, The game has it's own little charm but suffers from the common overly reused graphics syndrome.  You will find many enemy reskins and most maps are just randomlly generated with slight alterations. Despite this, it really holds up very well.  It kinda does bother me when characters are talking and the game decides to cut in for only a few seconds only to show characters doing something subtle like a hand gesture or a simple mouth movement.  I don't remember if this was the case on the PS2 version as it has been a while since I have played it.

(Spoilers here)
Story is pretty interesting, simply put you are playing a game that goes skynet and puts people all around "The World" into a comatose.(Pun intended)  This boi Tri-Edge slaps your girl's butt and you aren't about to take that and end up getting your face smacked to the floor so hard you go back to level 1.  Later on you go on to solve the mysteries of Tri-Edge and come across best girl. Eventually you save the world from a deadly MMO that was still allowed to continue running despite the cultural backlash and almost dumping a can of whoopass all over the planet.
(End Spoilers)

The soundtrack is really good, it was composed by the same person who did the previous games and you can tell  Chikayo Fukuda has only gotten better with age. 

The Combat works like this,  you engage into a battle which creates a ring in which you fight enemies.   The increased fps has caused some issues from its former PS2 varient in which tap weapons require a weird timing that its almost better to just use charge attacks.  You will have access to 5 different weapons each with their own style of gameplay and each weapon can be used mid battle depending how you setup your skill triggers.  It's pretty straight forward and the game is by no means difficult if you lose in battle it's probably only because you are underleveled as enemies damage seems to stagnate to oneshot levels otherwise. 

Mechanically the game gets extremely repetitive and leveling becomes ridiculously easy, I don't by any means think its a bad game.  If you are looking for a mindless game then play .hack//GU because its still quite fun.  Menus are easily navigated and there is memoir section if you forget what you need to do.  Party Members you want may not always be available due to how the story progresses.  Armor and Weapons can be rigged to insanely overpowered levels but this has always been the case since the PS2 version. You get a little mini desktop that you can decorate and play a idle mini game called Crimson VS which  plays itself as you play the game.   Lots of lore and flavortext to be found on the pretend online fourms and news of the outside world of the game located in the news section.  

Is this game worth playing?  Yes, if you are a fan of the series otherwise find another game because you will probably be bored out of your mind.

In retrospect, what seemed like a great and flowing combat system during the PS2 era has fallen flat,  with the single button commands and sometimes simplistic combat commands that existed in the original 3 volumes having lost their impact.

The story is great and the cast of charachters seems to really come to life through the mail, party and crimson systems, however the open map and the repetitiveness of the encounters in the field system can detract from the engagement of the narrative.

While this is a great game for nostalgia, it pales in comparison to games which have updated their combat mechanics, even without changing graphics, such as Tales and Star Ocean.

TLDR: Only buy for Nostalgia and Story

38489308.review:
The most amazing "inside a MMORPG" game

This game is about an average player that wants revenge on a hacker that messed up with his friend. At first, Haseo is a rebel young guy who treats everyone poorly and thinks he can do everything by himself. But as the story progresses, he grows as a person, and a lot starts to change in his objective as the truth unveils.

The port is decent. The game has this old PS2 game look to it, but it's easy to get used to it. The only problem I had was with the shadows - having them activated would sometimes kill my FPS randomly (like staring at a door would make it go below 20fps). There is a notable slowdown when many effects are happening at the same time, but this problem was also present on the PS2 and doesn't happen often

The controls are a bit clunky at first, considering the combat is action-oriented (it doesn't have the same flow of Bayonetta and DmC, for example). It's something you get used to as well, especially with animation cancelling

There were some additions to the game, like the cheat mode, which puts you in the max level and gives you a ton of items and gold. The experience gain after battles has been increased, which makes the pacing a lot better (you will outlevel some story dungeons that were supposed to be used to level though). The terminal disc is included, which contains videos about the .hack games before G.U. and some more info about what's going on

The addition of a new volume is debatable. The story feels complete at the end of Vol 3, and Vol 4 seems to be a "good ending" to the series. It suffers from bad design though, like making you talk to every ally before a big battle (so they can say 2 phrases), and the new mechanics are only available for several dungeons. All in all, it seems to be an advertisement for a new series

In the end, the G.U. series is amazing and definitely worth buying. The game runs well, the story is very interesting, and it's easy to get used to the game's limitations

Overall I would definitely recommend anyone that loves RPGS and MMOs to play this amazing series because it was truly a great experience.

38306706.review:
Honestly one of the best RPGs I've played in years. its fun, pretty, with an exciting story. 21 hours in and I've finished volume 1 (of 4), and loved every second of it. I'm now actually going out of my way to do some completionist things before moving on to volume 2, which is out of character for me.

quick pros and cons:

PROS:
-cutscenes are crisp and pretty
-voice acting is mostly good for an "anime" type game
-combat is solid, fun, and simple if you wanted to be, more complex if not
-same goes for equipment 
-LOTS of things to collect and do, if you're into it. All optional, though. 
-many QOL changes from the original release, but I can't name many since I never played those. Things like faster move speed, AI party members kicking chims for you, etc
-The music is memorable and enjoyable
-The "desktop" outside of the game itself, along with the forums and continuing news stories for world building

CONS:
-areas are very limited. Aside from the special story areas, most everything looks pretty similar. I didn't feel this took away from the experience, though, yet I do hope this isn't the case for volumes and onward
-the game is very generous with exp, and it is easy to overlevel without trying. Fights meant to be challenging were sometimes cakewalks, though a cerain post game boss was still a challenge despite this. 
-in engine cutscenes don't have lip movement. not something that bothers me, but something that's worth mentioning

So, yeah, I'd definitely recommend this based just on the first volume. I'll update the review as I go on. Maybe.

初代.hack経験者なのでそれを加味した上でのレビュー。
Corei7 GTX770というスペックだが、報告されるようなフリーズや強制終了は一切なくvol.1-vol.4までクリア。

「The World」と言うオンラインゲーム内で巻き起こる意識不明者続出事件を追いかけるプレイヤー達の物語。

・GOOD
【戦闘】戦闘は前作に比べて遥かに進化した。前作では敵に近づき連打で通常攻撃をしつつも弱点属性のスキルを使い続けるという単調なものであったが今作ではアクション性が大きくなりガードや回避などを使いつつ敵を攻め、ワンボタンで使いたい技を使えるようになり非常に楽しかった。

・BAD
【シナリオ、世界観】この作品はシリーズ物であり、前作はPS2でしかプレイ出来ずこの作品からプレイした人には話は正直訳がわからないと思う。前作ゲームだけではなく、かつて放映されていたアニメも見ないと繋がりが不明な部分もあるため今作以外でも補完しなければならない部分が多い。また、世界観としても主人公という人物がプレイしているオンラインゲーム内での話であるためオンラインゲームを遊んだ事のない人には伝わりにくい慣習や雰囲気があり、どこまでいっても所詮はオンラインゲーム内での話という事でシナリオには緊張感は薄い。また演出も日本アニメ的になっているのでそれが嫌な人にとってはうんざりする展開や演出が多くなる。

【武器グラフィックが見えない】ゲーム中様々な武器を入手することがもちろんあるのだが、デザインが良いのにそれを見れるのは戦闘中だけというのは残念。前作では武器は出しっぱなしであったのでズームで武器を見たり、レア武器であれば残光が移動時に出るので特別感があってかっこよかったがそれが全て無くなっている。

・総評・
戦闘システムは非常に良く、60FPSで遊べるようになり更に爽快感や快適度が増している。レベルも上がりやすいので少し強いエリアで敵を倒していればクリアには全く苦労しないので遊びやすい。しかしながら、オンラインゲームをしない人には設定が馴染みにくく前作やTVアニメのネタが多いのでこの作品だけで世界観・設定を全て把握するのが難しいため楽しめるとは言い難い。また、シナリオの質も個人的には前作の方が細かく出来ていたので良かったと思う。

38220330.review:
I've played the first volume and 30 minutes of the second. 70% of the game was not enjoyable. I think the gameplay is hit or miss. A little simple, but maybe that's fine. My problems are mostly with the game's story, and this is what this review will cover. Spoiler alert btw.

---The Good---
This is a game where you play as a person playing an MMO called "The World". You are able to play "The World", or log out and be on your desktop. Here, you can open forums and news websites to get information about "The World" and "the real world" (the fictional real world outside the fictional MMO). This is where you will get most of your world building, and the only thing I thought was great about this game's storytelling. You can read about real-world events like rockets being sent to space, or watch some trashy news program (trashy in the sense that most things on TV these days are kinda bad) that is closely related to what happens in "The World". The forums provide world building for "The World", and it makes you feel like there is an active player base for "The World" (even if it is all fake). You friends (in the game), also use this forum, and you can learn a few things about them through here.

This was what made me go over my 2-hour refund playtime, and I hate how the world building was good enough to make me play for 20 more hours.

---The Bad---
The rest of the story is really bad. Or... Well... It is delivered really badly. You are this main character called Haseo, who got PK'ed (Player Killed) on his first day in "The World", by the players who learned him the basics. This serves as the tutorial, and it kinda treats you like you are an idiot, who can't remember what they are told. I normally don't have a problem with this in tutorials, but I'll get back to this later.
After this tutorial, you a treated with a cutscene from 8 months later. You learn that Haseo has become a PKK (PK Killer), and is known as the Terror of Death. The reason for this is that during these 8 months he had a friend who got PK'ed by someone called Tri-Edge and ended up in a coma IRL because of it. So basically Haseo is seeking revenge.
He finally finds Tri-Edge, who then performs some weird supernatural thing on Haseo, and after that, he is back to level 1. So far, this is fine. It establishes some motivations and end goals.
After this Haseo meets with two new tutorial guys, and they start trying to help him just like before. Haseo tells them that he knows all the shit already, but they don't believe him, so they go with him on a "quest". Still no problem. THEN DURING THE FUCKING MISSION, THESE TUTORIAL GUYS TELL HASEO SOMETHING HE DOESN'T FUCKING KNOW! HOW? HOW DOES THIS HAPPENED? HASEO WAS LEVEL 133 OR SOMETHING! HE SHOULD FUCKING KNOW EVERYTHING! HE WAS A FAMOUS PKK, WHO NOBODY COULD BEAT!

Ok, ok... It's fine... NO, IT'S FUCKING NOT! This keeps happening during the story. Apparently. Haseo doesn't know about "The Arena", a place where official PvP matches take place or most things about guilds (even though he's been in one).

Now you might be saying: "Don't be stupid baka baka. If they didn't tell Haseo, then how would you, the player, know about all this.". Yes, that is a valid point, but then why did the game do the "after 8 months" cutscene when it did. It could have waited, have you join Haseo first guild, have you join Haseo in his first arena battle because he wanted to get stronger for revenge. Then, after this, we could have had this cutscene. All problems solved.

Sadly, this disconnect between what Haseo should know and what he actually knows is not the only problem with this game. Remember what I said about the first tutorial. The entire game is like this. Every time you go into a room and the doors lock, you get: "You can put in these spheres and then the doors will open.". Every time Haseo read an email telling him where to go, he then repeats it in his head. THEN WHEN YOU LOG INTO "THE WORLD", HE SAIS IT AGAIN! WHY?!?! IM NOT A FUCKING IDIOT! ONE TIME IS ENOUGH! Also, after every major plot point, Haseo will end all cutscenes with: "Well, I guess I will go check my email or something.". This happens without exception (this could be a fun drinking game). The problem here is, that you will get a popup when you actually get an email, so there is no reason for him to say it.

Ok, so I've deviated a little from the plot, let's get back to that. Haseo get's to know this girl Atoli, who looks exactly like his friend in a coma. This girl seems to kinda fall for him(?) or at least wants his attention really badly. The problem here is, that I really don't see why she cares. Haseo is only ever a jerk to her. He literally bad mouths her guild, the first time they meet. When she then tries to show him what she cares about in "The World", like looking at the scenery and taking it easy, he verbally abuses her, tell her to never show her face again. Why does she care for Haseo? Why hasn't she at least blocked him? She probably even has the rights to report him.

Btw, Haseo is also an awfully unlikeable character, if you haven't already noticed. Now, I really don't like to call things "edgy", as it is the most uninforming thing people can say as criticism. Sadly, Haseo tries his hardest to be this edgy guy, who cares about no one and always tries to say this "cool" and sarcastic lines to whoever he talks to. Sadly, he is never cool, and all his lines sound fucking stupid, especially when he talks to people smarter than him, and gets his word showed back up his ass. He also didn't have any character growths in all the time I played the game. You would think that after his verbal harassment nearly gets Atoli hurt badly (because she does something to get his attention), that he would stop... Sadly, he still just yells at her at the start of volume two, soo... And it's not like he doesn't care for Atoli (I think). It seems to me, that he seems to regret things whenever he actually hurts his friends... That is, when they tell him, that he hurt them. This is especially true for Atoli.

The dialog in this game is also fucking awful. The English dub is partly to blame, but I assume that they are just reading the subtitles, so even if I had Japanese on, it would still be the same. There is one point where Atoli's voice is kinda weird, and they other people say that they can't hear her. So I assume that this weird voice is to portray her thoughts to me, the player, but NOPE! Everyone responds to her when she talks, and when she tells her guild master about what happened HE LITERALLY SAIS: "Oooh, so that's why I can't hear you.". This was where I was about to drop everything. Maybe this is a translation issue, but I can't understand Japanese, so the original script is useless to me.

I think you all get the point by now. If you don't care about the story, or if all this is not a problem, then this may be a game for you. It seems that a lot of people actually enjoy this game, I mean, look at all the positive reviews. I think the premise is strong, and there are some interesting supernatural mysteries that I still want to know the answer to. Sadly, if a story is gonna do something for 27 hours, then it is likely that the rest is done the same way, so I'm done.

38218672.review:
.Hack G.U. the second series in the series that popularized the "mmo" plot. With its 15 year anniversary we have this collection release giving all 3 volumes in one quick access launcher and a previously unreleased 4th volume along with small extras here and there. I've decided to split the review up slightly between the volumes and it should go without saying there's likely to be some spoilers in this, but I will try to avoid as many major ones I can.

Volumes 1-3 

The original ps2 games. These games do slightly show their age. They upscale the graphics as much as they can, but they can't exactly upgrade the gameplay, which is a little dated. To be fair however their gameplay was repetitive even back when they were new. The "jrpg" curse of being very repetitive is present here but its surprisingly one of the less offensive even in recent memory due to how it is structured. There is also the option now of using what the game calls cheat mode, essentially a "tell me a story" difficulty this cuts out all leveling and gear hunting and just lets you experience the story. For anyone else actually interested how the game plays keep reading.

This game uses scaling to base how its entire system is structured, to put this simply a core statistic (typically your level) is picked by the game to "weigh" more than others and has much more bearing on how the other statistics will perform. So in .Hack level is everything. You could have 1 million HP, but if enemy was 20 levels higher than you it'd still kill you in just a few hits. Once you realize this the game will feel a grind at first cause you feel shoehorned into leveling, except G.U. is the extreme end of this scaling so it allows leveling to be abused. The tolerance gap is 10 levels, if you fight anything outside of 10 levels from you the scaling gets extreme and murders you quickly, but if you stay just on the bleeding edge of the 10 levels you gain experience extremely fast and cap out for the respective volume in around just a couple hours each volume if that. That brings me to something else that should be discussed, the volume splits.

Back in the ps2 era these volumes were completely separate games connected solely by the player's save data, one of the larger hopes when they released Re;code would be they connected the games together fully. They did not do this but instead put them all in a sort of emulated launcher which while is not ideal, it works well enough. It also shows the progression of the series very clear as each volume got more added to it, vol 1 feeling very barren. This kinda adds to the pseudo mmo feel as this makes you feel like you're experiencing content updates. Which of course is important to the whole experience of giving you a fake mmo experience.

This comes to the biggest draw of the games, the pseudo mmo experience and its story. This is the thing that kept me playing despite faults, I loved the story and setting of this series. They go to great lengths to try to make you feel immersed in a fictional breathing world, from other players posting on forums and communicating, to world news posts explaining the issues of this game's "real" world. This latter aspect also becomes an interesting time capsule showing what were issues back when the game was made, and can be neat in its own right. The main plot of the games can be a little hard to follow at times as it never truly explains some aspects and leaves it up to the imagination, this is fine so long as you take it simply as that. In all the characters and story to me are the biggest selling point of the game and kept me playing even through its more dull points. 

I would have had a very large complaint on them releasing G.U. without the original .hack cause people would be lost story wise if not for one thing, they had the forethought to include the terminal disc from the original ps2 release. The terminal disc was an extra mode that is purely story content that not only explains the original .hack which is handy for people new to the series, it also explains some of the real world happenings leading up to and during G.U.

Vol 4 Reconnection

This will be short as the game itself is pretty dang short, vol 4 can be finished in about 2 hours. This new volume was an extra that came with the re;code repackaging that concludes the G.U. story pretty much definitively. I sort of have a mixed feeling about this, without spoilers there is a bonus ending in vol 3 that acted as the true end at the time, and while it left some things up in the air, I thought it was a decent enough ending. Vol 4's ending and content puts a very bittersweet feeling to how everything ends which I am not sure I like. As for the gameplay there's not much to say as you barely get to play anything and most of the games features are disabled in this volume. The games cut scenes take step forward and step back at the same time by being fully animated yet having some uncanny motion to them, making them feel sort of stop motion.

Its clear to me that they took what they had of the at the time canceled vol 4 and stitched it together so the game could run. The story becomes boarderlne incoherent at points as the "middle" that would fill in details is missing, it jumps from main story beat to main story beat till it finishes. In all there's not much to complain about I guess if you think of this simply as an extra to the whole package, but if you were going to get this purely for Reconnection, I'd think about it a bit more.

In all however the package is great for its price and still a top notch story as long as we leave vol 4 out of the equation. I recommend this.

38206209.review:
[h1]Welcome to The World[/h1]

Такими словами приветствует нас игра, когда главного героя убивают PK (Убийцы Игроков) на первом же квесте. The World представляет собой MMORPG в которую играют используя VR-шлем. Как и в любой MMO здесь бывают особо подлые PvP-моменты, но с недавних пор в игре появился PK именуемый Tri-Edge, чьи жертвы после смерти в виртуальном мире, впадают в кому уже в реальном (и это за 6 лет до SAO). Хасео - наш подопечный, стал свидетелем нападения этого игрока на его подругу (с характерным результатом) и теперь желает возмездия. 

Завязка в 2006-ом году весьма интриговала, а походу прохождения вообще превращалась в 
хорошо продуманную историю длиною в 3 тома. Сыграть в этот сборник стоит хотя бы ради этого. Ибо повествование вышло захватывающим, а сама проработка "имитации" MMORPG превосходит даже новые игры по Sword Art Online. 

В Last Recode включили  всю трилогию G.U. с PS2 и добавили немало нового:
[list]
[*]Новая игра - эпилог всей истории - Vol. 4
[*]Cheat Mode - для тех, кто хочет пробежать по сюжету.
[*]Ребаланс игры - уменьшили гринд и добавили возможность повторить битву после поражения.
[*]Terminal Disc - энциклопедия о вселенной включающая информацию о предтечи - квадрологии оригинального .Hack.
[*]Parody Mode - забавный кинотеатр, в котором можно посмотреть ролики переозвученные оригинальными актёрами, но каардинально меняющие смысл происходящего вплоть до полного бреда. С некоторых посмеялся от души. 
[/list] 
Геймплей, к сожалению, устарел и вызывает скуку. Бои происходят в реальном времени прямо на месте столкновения. В первой части всё ограничивалось блоком, ударом и спецприёмом (+ его же парирующая разновидность Rangeki). Во второй уже стало лучше - дали возможность через спецприём менять одно из трёх типов оружия. В третьей боёвка стала достаточно интересной и ближе к современным аналогам JRPG.

Про внешний вид говорить особо нечего - немного подтянутая графика с PS2 и перерисованные ролики под высокое разрешение.

Зато много всего хочется сказать о техническом исполнении ПК-версии. Она странная. В игре напрочь отсутствует frameskip, чем обычно промышляют файтинги, но никак не JRPG. Если у вас будет ниже 60 FPS готовьтесь к слоу-мо и "Подергиваниям" экрана. Игра очень активно жрёт процессор. На видеокарту ей по большей части побоку - есть 1Gb и ладно. Так что, владельцы бюджетных ПК и ноутбуков весьма удивлятся производительности PS2-переиздания. 

Ну да ладно. Допустим, у вас всё хорошо с этим, но тут появляются ещё три проблемы - игра не видит крестовину у Xbox-геймпада! Вообще никак. А она нужна для переключения прицела и ввода команд при попадании в ловушку (тут я и заметил, что она не пашет). Пришлось настраивать через стороннее ПО.  Со вторым я столкнулся недавно. Игра работает на Win10 по своему желанию. Иногда запускается, а иногда говорит, что нет поддержки Dx11 (вообще офигеть). На Win7 такого нет, так, что не знаю кто именно виноват. Третья проблема - вылетает на битве с финальным боссом в Vol. 2. Случайно. Недавний патч не исправил этой проблемы.

Коллекция сама по себе в купе с бонусами просто отличная (не каждый в качестве доп. контента запилит ещё одну игру), но означенные выше минусы технического плана несколько омрачают знакомство с чудным миром MMORPG "The World". Будем надеятся, что разработчики это починят в ближайшее время.

P. S. Переиздание оригинальных четырёх игр серии (Те, что про Кайта) тоже бы не помешало.

38200100.review:
So I have been a fan of .hack for about a good 10 years now and when I heard that Last Recode was coming out with a new volume I was very excited. To those of you who havent played .hack before granted this isnt the best starting point but it should do if you wanna get interested in the series (The original Quadrilogy you cant get anymore but you can probably still watch the anime for it.)
(Warning I will probably spoil a tiny bit of Volume 4 but only in a gameplay sense)

The first game of this series Rebirth feels a little bit sluggish from the other 3 games. The story can start off a bit slow and you will be doing a lot of grinding that doesnt feel contributes to the game. That being said if you can get through the first game you will be through most of the slow parts of the game (When I mean slow parts I mean that the story feels like it doesnt progress as well as the other games do.)

The second game is personally my favourite out of the original GU games because it fixes a lot of problems that the first game had. The new Multi-Trigger system allows you to change weapons on the fly when you use that weapons skill. So say if you wanna switch from Dual Sword to Scythe you can do so while in battle instead of having to change and waiting like a few seconds in battle to switch from the first game. This story will tear you up it probably has the most character development and if you are emotionally attached to characters you will learn a bit more about them.

The Third game in the series is my second favourite cause it keeps the same formula as all the other games. Haseo grows a lot in personality and learns a lot from every person you have met in the world. This game is probably the game you will be spending the most Post game time on instead of the actual game because there is a LOT to do at the end of this game. Back when I played this I probably spent 10 hours on the main game with 30-40 hours in Post Game. 

And then we get to Volume 4. Which honestly shouldnt be called its own volume but rather half of a volume with nothing but linear storyline. When you open up Volume 4 EVERYTHING you could do on the desktop you cannot access. When you go through the game you will soon realize that there is no free roam of what you want to do. The game locks you to the story and it feels very iffy. I feel like after all this work I have done in the post game for Volume 3 to only find everything locked it doesnt feel good. However this probably has one of the best endings to the .hack GU franchise and it feels really good at the end. Unfortunately due to what happens once you get to a certain part of the game you cannot use any weapons that you worked up for. It locks you to the one weapon you have to use. It looks cool dont get me wrong but I feel like it feels so bad that all the weapons you worked up for you can never use EVER again.

I havent looked into the Terminal Disc but I checked out the Parody mode and I could not stop laughing watching Parody mode. I would highly recommend checking both of those out but only after you have beat all 4 games.

Nonetheless .hack GU despite how Volume 4 locks you in story and theres no post game, .hack GU Last Recode feels like an awesome remaster of the first 3 games and Volume 4 feels like it wrapped up the series very well. If you havent gotten into .hack I HIGHLY recommend playing these games. And hopefully if this gets enough love then maybe I can always hope for a real .hack MMO (Like an actual MMORPG of "The World" aside from Fragment.) 

(This is my first review so I hope I got my points across very well!)

alright so this is an amazing port. I've loved these games since it first came out on PS2, as well as .hack//IMOQ. I remember the day the announcement was made that GU was going to be a thing as me and my best friend in middle school were so fucking excited about this. we watched the trailers over and over on her shitty internet after school. and then they finally came out!! We played the fuck outta these games. I'm a real adult now with a job and I get to experience this all over again!!! (with my fiance watching - alkaid is waifu and she agrees)

if I'm going to be honest, the only negative bit I've got about this port is I wish they would've added a difficulty setting. at it's normal playthrough it's honestly way too easy to just pop into a field ten levels higher and just power grind yourself. mind you the ps2 ver was decently easy as well, especially compared to the first .hack series.. they made this port a little too easy. or maybe i'm just a seasoned gamer now :(

regardless, this game is a 10/10 if you like story driven RPGS. and while I'm older now and have some issues with parts of the plot, at it's heart this game has plenty to take from, as well as pretty good character growth. 

now here's to hoping they remaster Kite's series!!!! :)

38100262.review:
Bon, après avoir fini ce jeu, au bout de plus de 120 heures, je me suis dit qu'il était temps de donner le verdict.

Bon, Ben, je recommande, pour plusieurs raisons:

- C'est .Hack//G.U., l'un des pans les plus épiques de toute la saga .Hack.

- Les personnages sont attachants, en fait, ils sont la force majeure des jeux dû au fait qu'ils sont, en un sens, la force motrice de l'histoire, ainsi, les suivre accentue l'immersion dans l'univers proposé.

- Les graphismes ont bien vieilli : pour une série de jeux sortie vers la fin des années 2000, ça reste encore beau a voir, et encore plus si on prend en compte le fait que là, c'est un remaster HD.

38060336.review:
READ CONCLUSION FIRST IF YOU TL;DR.

HD remaster of PS2 games + a short vol 4 to give a closing. Has its issues but not a bad port (I'm looking at you, Fractured But Whole).

Bad things: 

* Random Crashes, which are not often.
* Difficulty (laughable, but we are waiting for difficulty mods).
* Poor graphic optimization (makes FPS drop to 30 or below in cities), which can be turned off for performance and it still looks beautiful (or you can just add a mod that fix this)

Good things:

* Amazing story that happens in a MMORPG
* Fun gameplay (though it can be outdated to today standards, but remember; it's a 2006 game)
* "web and forum interaction", meaning you can read forums (which you can get wallpapers, advices and unlock in-game stuff) and news that tells the current state of that universe (everything electronic and computarized, VR goggles, etc), which basically mirrors our current world (though this game was released in 2006).

Note: This game offers 20 hs average per volume, and it offers replayability to max everything. Also has data transfer, so if you finish game 1 and use that save for game 2 everything you had carries over.

Conclusion: Buy it on sale or after a patch, because unless you're a fan of the saga, 50 bucks (though I got it cheaper) for a game that crashes is not worth it, even though you're actually paying 50 bucks for 4 games.

38025675.review:
I was a fan of the .hack//Quarantine series and picked this up to relive some nostalgia.

I was really surprised. Currently still on Rebirth, so if things change through the series I'm unaware of it. In my opinion, these games individually are worth the single price tag alone still if you are a fan of the series, so 4-in-1 is a great value.

Pros:
-Excellent remastering. The graphics weren't the only thing they touched on and there was clearly a LOT of work that went into this, it wasn't just a nostalgia cash grab.
-The remastered graphics actually look pretty good. It's not current-gen by any means, but there's times you'll have trouble believing this game is 11 years old.
-The combat is not quite what I loved from the Quarantine series, but it's still unique and fun and it keeps the player engaged.
-Tons of content. Like, a lot. The .hack world is so well built, it's a shame The World never made it to a full blown MMORPG spinoff in NA. Plus, this is 4-games in one.
-The option to either play through the game as it was originally intended, or accelerated with a built-in cheat mode if all you care about is the story. Very nice player comfort feature.
-Content is not just within the game itself. There's a simulated social hub featuring clips and stories that is actually really well done.

Cons
-Character voice acting is inconsistent. Sometimes it's great, other times it's awful.
-Not a fan of the generation or combat in this series. The Quarantine series felt a lot more open to me, but it's fair to say there are benefits to this style as well.
-Game is 11 years old. While this is a proper remaster with a lot of new content, it still suffers from the limitations of 11 year old mechanics.
-Not releasing a Quarantine remaster before this. Playing the Quarantine series at the very least is helpful to understanding what's going on in the story. If you are new to the series, I'd highly recommend playing the first half of the .hack games first.

Here's to hoping this remastering was intended to help a new team develop a next-gen .hack game.

37958218.review:
Played this game back when it came out on Playstation 2, but the opinion still applies to the PC version. dotHack franchise is rather diverse in that it includes anime, manga and games, the latter being more recognizable even in western world. That doesn't mean that this particular game would be difficult to play without prior knowledge received through anime series or earlier .hack 4-part game. But it would add more to the experience. 

As the game by itself it has pretty good action combat (although it might get rather repetetive later on), likable characters and very good music.  And even though it's a game about people playing a game it manages to be serious when it is needed. It won't take too long to beat it when playing just for the main story, boss fights are not really too challenging, but it wouldn't hurt to try and get into the whole "The World" setting with logging into your game, interacting with other players via emails and reading outside world news describing the events tied into the story.

Graphics do show that this is a PS2 game, but all the minimal options like resolution, shadows, antialiasing are present. Voiceover can be switched between English and Japanese. Controls can be remapped for keyboard or better yet just use the gamepad. It is better optimized for that type of control.

Overall it is a solid game which may interest people who are into JRPGs. 


And hey, it was earlier than Sword Art Online!

37950698.review:
With all the new jrpgs coming to steam, I hoped that .hack might one day come as well since it's one of my favorite series.  THE TIME IS NOW, with an extra epilogue even!
First, going to start off with Volume 4

Volume 4 was made on a budget, and is moreso a playable epilogue than an actual chapter.  I finished it in a bit under 2 and half hours.
Instead of cutscenes, a majority of the story is told through incredibly janky looking anime scenes.  The new form is pretty fun to play as, for the one dungeon you're able to.

Much, much more enjoyable to play with the graphical improvements and most importantly, 60 fps.  Gameplay, story, and ost (apart from a few very, very repetitive tracks) are all still excellent.  The achievements aren't anything special, you'll get 99% of them from naturally playing the game.  There's no grindy achievements, or "find this secret!" types.

The port is one of the best I've seen of all the jrpgs currently ported.  The title screen is a game selection one, with additional options for the Terminal Disk and Parody Mode (which is amazing)
I haven't experienced a crash or any sort of slowdown in the 124 hours I have clocked in.  There's some basic quality settings; shadows, anti-aliasing, and texture filtering.  You're able to choose either the english dub or the original japanese voices.

Note that you CAN play this with a keyboard.  The control settings are located in the "Steam" subsection, which you can open on the title screen with Q (by default)

37898025.review:
I would only recommend this game if you played the original .hack series and have an interest in either feeling some nostalgia or simply like the flashy but simplified fighting style that g.u. brought to the .hack universe. The game expects you to know things are important from the original game series as well as .hack // sign and if you are coming in without any background knowledge this game will feel incredibly disjointed and confusing. 

I originally avoided picking up g.u. because I thought the idea of Skeith/the other phases being used as fanservice was increidbly irritating. I never liked the idea of something that was supposed to be this terrifying fragment of corrupted data that would data drain humans resulting in them becoming comatose being turned into this "cool" anime thing you are supposed to be cheering for when he appears. The worst example of this is the abomination Gorre being turned into a cutesy set of twin robots but that is just my personal gripe with the concept of Avatars. 

After managing to ignore these issues I enjoyed the games for what they were and had fun. The avatar battles are incredibly easy but there were some satisfying moments in seeing Skeith data draining your nemeses at the end of a battle. Combat overall is done fairly well but the weapons besides the daggers are largely useless unless you want to juggle enemies that are significantly higher than your level. Also, I feel like the dodging ability in part 3 should have been part of the entire series but that is just my opinion. The story has some pacing issues mainly with an obnoxious pink dog-eared warlock wanting you to do side quests randomly but other than that was well written and enjoyable. 

The games get gradually better as they go along with the exception of the added part 4 so if (when) you find yourself trodding through the seemingly endless trivial and almost insulting objectives in part 1 do know that the games do eventually pick up. 

And sort of spoiler warning but I do sincerely hope that what Piros says at the end of part 4 turns out to be true and not just in-game chatter.

Overall, I recommend it, if you just want the story then go through in cheat mode at max level and don't worry about achievements.

37855360.review:
.Hack//G.U. Last Recode es una compilación remasterizada de tres de videojuegos de esta emblemática serie JRPG lanzada originalmente para PS2. El lanzamiento del recopilatorio presenta una resolución de hasta 4K, así como otras mejoras gráficas y ajustes jugables. A su vez, incluye una secuela a su tetralogía original, conformada por Rebirth, Reminisce y Redemption. 

The World es donde transcurren los hechos de estas entregas, un juego MMO no real dentro del título, recordemos que es de la época de la aclamada PS2, la cual no contaba con semejante potencia.
En este título encarnamos a Haseo, un sujeto que debido a un altercado al comienzo del primer volumen se convierte en una maquina extremadamente poderosa de asesinar jugadores que se dedican a eliminar a otros jugadores dentro de The World, los conocidos Player Killers o PK. Pero debido a un enemigo conocido como Tri-Edge su poder se ve reducido a Nivel 1 y a partir de aquí comienza la aventura. 

Posee una trama muy bien creada y narrada; realmente buena y muy madura. Tiene además una gran cantidad de contenido y escenas estilo anime. Estas remasterizaciones traen muchas mejoras, e incluyen el capítulo inédito Reconnection. 

Dado a la época en la cual fue originalmente creado, cada volumen tiene corta duración, pero entre todos puede darte mínimo unas 70 horas de juego. Otro punto en contra es que, nueva mente por la edad del original, el combate puede resultar un tanto antiguo, anticuado; pero no es injugable.

Realmente una muy buena jugada por parte de Bandai Namco; si bien no es su serie más famosa la saga .hack goza del apoyo por parte de muchos jugadores quienes jugaron originalmente a estos títulos. Es una vuelta al pasado y a la juventud de muchos veteranos en los videojuegos, que da la posibilidad de recordar viejas tardes luego de la escuela jugando a la consola o noches enteras de verano tratando de superar algún jefe o mazmorra. Un completo punto a favor para la compañía que se atrevió a desempolvar esos viejos recuerdos.

37847070.review:
I remember playing this game on PS2 many years ago and throughly enjoyed all the 3 volumes, almost getting everything 100% completion, only didn't do so because something glitched in the second volume and I didn't feel like reloading MANY hours of gameplay just for one quest. Anyway, I always hoped the series would get a new game over the years but to have a sort of remastered version along with a brand new chapter was enough to me for now!

Overall they made some quality of life changes making some small things go faster/easier with this new version but I don't feel like that negatively affected my gameplay. 

The combat is fairily simple and to today's standards it feels old but it's not necessarily bad. I personally didn't have a problem with it when playing in the PS2 neither have any problems playing now. But if you end up not enjoying it you probably won't like the rest of the battles through the game because it basically feels the same thing even with the different weapon styles.

Without mentioning much spoilers the story feels a bit cliche at first like it's just a revenge tale but it grows to something deeper and the characters has some pretty good development too which did stood out for me as I played. 

The music was very well done and it has some fantastic themes but I felt it sometimes was a bit repetitive if you're grinding areas for exp or items or even sidequests objectives. Like the same field songs playing over and over as you run through the zones.

Which brings me to the map variety, it's not great at all, while there are a LOT of possible zones combinations with the keyword system they dont bring too much variety aside just level gaps, so that may be a problem for some. 

It's far from a perfect game but even despite the flaws it still is a fantastic JRPG and I'm very happy it got a new edition. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the genre and if you played the original .Hacks from PS1 this is definitely a must play for you!

37787902.review:
《再诞》-->《思念之声》-->《漫步之速》-->《重连》-->to be continue...
       十余年了，没想到又能玩上这款佳作（而且是高清重制版，外加一个vol4章节）......当初小小的自己凭着一腔热血和执着，看不懂日文，硬是靠自己摸索和理(nao)解(bu)，带着眼泪打通了vol3。直至今日，我的双颊也被时光刻出了棱角，但那个由黑变白的少年的身影依然时不时在眼前闪回......
       游戏一出就买了，30多小时认认真真的通了vol1，感受到了震撼、感动和诚意。按我自己的理解水平，一条一条分析：
          1.耐心的玩，你会发现游戏很简单，升级非常快，除了最终boss基本不会有什么难度（可能对玩惯了rpg的玩家来讲，直接就是没难度），这就是制作组对玩家游戏体验的重视。
          2.没难度，玩家才会自然地带着平静的心态去观赏剧情，这一点就是《.hack》系列的厉害之处。先不说强化了的画面，光是代入感极强的剧情本身都足以俘获玩家的心灵（英文不好的朋友嘛，emmmm...）。
          3.美型的人物、帅气的装备还有叹为观止的环境塑造都是吸引玩家眼球的地方，有趣的支线任务以及与npc、怪物们的互动也让玩家在主线的严肃、紧张之余笑点不断，保证不会让你在听故事时睡着。
       综合以上3点，《.hack/GU LastRecode》绝对是一款成功的重制作品（说“冷饭”感觉很对不起制作组，也会伤了我自己这样的粉丝的心），她为你准备了一桌满满的情感大餐，而且她绝对有耐心，也有能力，喂给你，让你慢慢地品尝，直至最后一口，然后余生难忘。
       十年前如此，今日，依旧如此。（事后p.s:天啊，我怎么忘了，还有超级耐听的音乐！！！）

37726847.review:
I played .hack//Infection and the rest of the original series when I was younger, but somehow had never heard of the .hack//G.U. series until recently. So I was ecstatic when it came to Steam and I could finally give it a shot. Unfortunately, I don't think it is an improvement in any way over the original IMOQ series. 

I cannot recommend this game to anyone who hasn't already played any other .hacks and enjoyed them enough to want to continue to build upon the story and atmosphere in the .hack universe.

The combat has taken an enormous step back with it now being battles that are sectioned off and cannot be escaped without an item. Not only that, but it's almost always a group of 3 enemies, or a single "hard" enemy that gets quite repetitive.

Areas have also changed for the worse. Instead of having open fields to run in with a dungeon somewhere within each landscape, now everything has a dungeon-like layout to it that has very little variation.

Data drain is now a very tedious mini-game that you are forced to play which always, every single time throughout the entire series, starts off without a brief tutorial message. It's really disheartening to think your audience is so incapable of performing a task you've forced them into doing 30+ times by the end of the series, and still think they don't know how to attack and dodge.

A new resource has been added to the game, probably to make up for lack of grunties and hunting for grunty food called Chim Chims. These creatures serve absolutely no purpose but to make you wait to progress. In order to collect chims, there are various ways to get them, but the most common is sitting next to a switch and waiting for some to come out and flipping the switch to knock them off tracks. These are always included next to the doors that Chim Chims open, so I cannot see any purpose they serve but to inhibit progress.

This game's narrative really tasks you with suspending your disbelief pretty early on, but by the 3rd game I felt so unimmersed by how high stakes the game becomes with seemingly no reason other than to "go bigger". The story trips upon itself multiple times by the very end by plotholes and how frequently the game moves it's own goalpost.

The addition of a new episode, Reconnection (vol. 4), is the most redeeming thing about Last Recode. Its story tones it down and makes it personal again. The cutscenes use a more traditional anime style that is absolutely gorgeous. The game has a good amount of closure that vol. 3 didn't really provide in the original G.U. trilogy. 

I can really only recommend this game to anyone who played the G.U. trilogy, but not the additional episode Reconnection, even on a sale.

Here's to hoping they remaster the Infection/Mutation/Outbreak/Quarantine series.

37721216.review:
Revisiting my childhood has never been better.

Ten years ago, I received my first console from my parents. Packaged with it was .hack G.U/ Rebirth. I played so much of that game, and the games that followed, and the G.U. series has been my favorite ever since. So I might be a little bias as I write this.

.hack has always been known for its dramatic stories that stray a little close to the melodramatic. G.U. is no different, but its loveingly crafted from start to finish. Haseo, as your playable protagonist, grows into being a hero (thank god, he's a bit of an ass in the beginning) and your supporting cast is full of great personalities. You'll have a hard time deciding on who to bring with you every time you venture out. 

The updated version released onto the PC is pretty stable, though I did notice that there are times were it will start dropping frames. A quick restart of the game fixes that, and you'll want to play it on the highest settings to see the updated graphics package, though just about any computer can run it. Experience is easy to gain now. You don't have to grind the same area words over and over again, and for those that just want to experience the story, there is cheat mode, which is basically an insta win setting for combat encounters. 

If you are looking for a solid JRPG with a lot to offer, look no further. You can't argue with the value of the package (4 games for $49.99, each around 15-20 hours long without attempting to 100% each game). Save data carries over from volume to volume, so that awesome piece of armor you picked up from God Eater at the end of vol. 2? Still on you when you start vol. 3 with some added goodies. 

It's good shit. Play it.

37708804.review:
Nostalgia trip from a decade passed, Last Recode reminds us of al lthe things good and ill of PS2 era JRPGs. Entirely too long cutscenes, strange plot pacing, obscenely huge monsters with questional shapes.

Over 4 games you'll get to toy with 5 different types of weapons. One thing Last recode absoutely nails is making each weapon feel different. THe dual swords feel fast and fluid, chaining huge combos with satisfying speed. THe broadsword feels like you're hitting someone with a truck. Somehow, the .//hack team made scythe combat interesting. Wide, sweeping arc attacks make you feel like a true grim reaper. And Dual guns let you chain combos and juggle enemies in mid air as only a JRPG could think to try.

The short but welcome new addition of Volume 4 creates this weird chain sword which behaves like nothing I've ever seen. But it also feels satisfying to use. 

Like I said in the intro, the pacing is garbage. In volume 1, you hit a grind that just doesn't seem to stop, then you end the grind, kill 2 bosses, and the volume is done. Volume 3 feels short, and volume 4 IS short. Characters don't always act like reasonable people. Or act their age (seriously, Sakaki is supposed to be 12. Haseo is supposed to be 17. Ovan is supposed to be 25. Yata is supposed to be about 15.) Atoli's voice acting is shrill. Gaspard's voice is infamous among the .//hack fans. the native japanese voice acting is here, if you can't get over the English voices. 

Overall, as a package, you're going to get over 100 hours of content. If you're a completionist, most likely 110 to 120. It's not my favorite .//hack story, but this is a good starting pint if you are new to the series.
