37568784.review:
I originally played these games on the PS2, so I knew what I was getting in terms of story and gameplay from this title. My biggest concern when buying this was the PC port. It being a PS2 Era, it should not be that hard to update it and make it run better. But at the same time, the port could be handled poorly and run like crap. 

I am here to report that the port of the game is functional, smooth, and feels amazing to play. That is Mainly what I based my recommend on. Of course, if you haven’t played a .hack game or even know the .hack series, I’ll fill you in on this extensive review.

[h1]Story[/h1]
.hack takes place in a pretty unique setting in a faux MMORPG game ‘The World’ which has been affected by internet phenomena out of bounds of the current game. The story of this game takes place after the events of an anime called .hack Roots. There a references to characters from that anime that appear in this game that you would have no context for if you didn’t watch the anime. This may bug some people. The game does a good enough job of explaining the events prior to the game through cutscenes referencing the main characters. There are also some tidbits and references through forum posts. There should be enough here to get the story without watching Roots, but the presence of some unexplained relationships can be off putting.

You follow a character by the name of Haseo, who is essentially your rpg edgelord. You start the story with essentially the very beginning of the.hack Roots anime. Two characters approach you with the pretense of teaching you the game. Then essentially comes the Tutorial, then the beginning of a big cutscene reel. The two characters that invited you are Player Killers (PKers) and do what they do best to you. While bullying you, the two get owned by the BEST character in the game. After that and the whole cutscene spiel, you essentially start again, and follow Haseo on his misadventure of gaining power, learning of the special characters called Epitath Users, and battling a virus hitting the world called AIDA. 

The story doesn’t really start taking off until Volume 2. But there is still enough in Volume 1, if maybe with not as many big plot points and crazy happenings that follow the world. The Characters you encounter along the way are all pretty likable, with perhaps the exception of the main character at least through most of Volume 1. Point is, the story is good, but there are little rivets here and there that can make it a little bit slow or cringy. Stick with it though, because Volume 2 on gets considerably better.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The loop of gameplay here is essentially, go read email, go do task in email, and then log out, and read email again. The loop is broken up often through world building like reading forum posts, doing optional quests, and playing special campaigns through the game that are offered. You may also break up the loop by going to grind. This is a pretty level driven game, equipment and levels can really make or break you sometimes.

Speaking of that, the game can either be easy if you use all the systems the game has in place or challenging if you do not. It is not impossible to beat the game without using everything, but being well prepared will always lend an easier time. Upgrading your and your party members equipment will show favorable results. Not doing that you may find yourself lacking some firepower. That said, there are a ton of party members in this game, so keeping them all updated is a bit hard. Pick your favorites and keep them fleshed out while the rest kinda just are there.

Combat in this game is simple but very fun. You have a basic combo, with a finisher depending on the weapon equipped. You have a charge attack. You have 4 skill slots you can easily activate, and you can also cast some magic skills if you want. You have access to more weapons the further you go in, with one per volume. There is also the Avatar Battles, which are nice break from the normal combat. You have a shot, a slash, and a dash and the battles all have some unique attacks and patterns to watch for. Really, this is probably the strongest part of the game for me.

[h1]Look & Feel[/h1]
60FPS smooth through most of the game, with some slowdowns with particularly particle heavy things, like awakenings, and some scenes. Though they also are a bit to conveniently placed and it almost feels like cinematic effect. Outside of that, it's silky smooth and fast to play. It feels really good.

Looks can be spotty, Textures and models are updated, but textures still look a little icky up close. Not only that, but there is an awful lot of texture clipping, especially with character models and different floor looks. I’ll often seen little jittery black likes of pixels in scenes as someone's foot clips through their cape or their hand through their armor. It doesn’t look ‘bad’ but it is a place that could have been improved to look even better. 

[h1]Other Stuff[/h1]
All the little extras and improvements that come with this game are nice. Ability to use items consecutively outside of combat. Faster leveling and weapon leveling. Faster paced battles with your higher damage output. It just makes the game all the better with all these little improvements. They did this in game, where in Volume 2 there were lots of changes that just made the game better present from the very get go. 

All these little things make the game worth buying, it is 4 games in 1, with good improvements and additions that just polish it up a little. There are certainly some things I would have liked changed (like the requirements for the campaigns and book of 1000 are still really high) but it is overall a nice touch here and there.

To wrap it up
This game is fairly priced for what it is. If you played these games and want to relive them, this is the best way to do it now. If you are new to .Hack, you may be lost, but I think the game stands well enough on its own. If you are not a fan of RPGS driven by story, avoid this. This hits a very small niche of people, and this is a very japanese game. But my final verdict is Recommend.

37553855.review:
I was sitting here, getting prepared to write some really long and elaborate piece about this game and how it compares to the original PS2 releases.  Instead of that, I'll just go over what changes I noticed and what I appreciated now.

While I do appreciate many of the changes they've made from the original releases such as the new wallpapers, speed ups for the running and bike animations in fields and towns, inclusion of japanese voice acting with the option of deciding what language you want to listen to as you play and a slight increase in the amount of exp earned in combat, there are things that I would have liked to have stayed the same.

The exp increase does make leveling faster, and the faster animations also affect some of the cut scenes throughout the story. This makes the whole thing seem very rushed as you get from point to point to point through all the games. If you like story driven games, having that feeling of 'hurry and get to the next point' diminishes the enjoyment of the story by a  great margin.

Would I recommend this game? Absolutely. It's an excellent step into the many mysteries of the .hack franchise and as far as RPGs go, this one fits pretty well into the standards that make up most RPGs of the time. Objectively speaking, I would give this game a 7 of 10 rating, but I do love the .hack series as a whole so my personal rating would be 9 of 10.

37509657.review:
I absolutely loved and played the .Hack GU trilogy to death. I played it tons on my PS2. I'd already played it so much that I could recite entire scenes without paying attention to it. I no longer had a PS2 and had one of the early PS3s that actually had backwards compatibility, but mine was one of those that needed updates first before a new PS2 game could be played, so when Redemption came out I actually had to wait a while before I could play it. I could list many faults with these games, but even despite those flaws, I would still rate them really highly, at least a 9/10. 

But I can't really say the same about the remaster. It's still the fun game series, and the games themselves havn't changed much, but while the remaster has introduced some great changes, it also introduces some negatives as well. There are more than enough reviews that gush about the remaster, but I want to note it's downsides. Even with the things I dislike about this master in mind, I still recommend this game though, especially if you were already a fan.

Also, I have not reached Vol. 4 yet. Just to let you guys know, but it should be irrelevant as my issues are with general changes to all of these games, and not really the story as that was left unchanged. Basically this review is not about the game itself, but the remaster.



I'm not one to garner interest by saving my most important point for last, it's going to be my first point, and that is the difficulty. In this remaster, they made it easier by giving you more EXP, and having you deal more damage, along with a bit of a faster combat speed. When I initially heard of these changes, I already didn't like them, but thought they were just tiny details I could just shrug off, not realizing how big they actually change things. It's much easier, even with the original game's lax difficulty in mind. You'll already feel like you're overleveled by just doing the main quests, but if you decide to go do some side quests, or even just some random field hopping, you're going to make the game way too easy. In the old games it was either too difficult because you were underleveled, or too easy because you grinded, but here you are not given that choice, it's just too easy. This leads to battles not being nearly as satisfying, and that's my biggest problem with this.

With the enhanced EXP and enhanced damage comes another issue, and that is GP, the game's currency. Unlike EXP, the amount you get was untouched. If you want to get some GP by fighting some battles, you're going to become easily overleveled, meaning to get GP you're forced to use methods that don't involve gaining EXP. This is less of an important note as the easiest and best ways to gain GP were not by battles, but it's still enough for me to consider it a negative.

The graphics are definitely improved, but it to me is both a negative and a positive. It definitely looks nicer, that's a good thing, the problem is the animation. In just normal cutscenes, the characters mouths don't move. It's not really anyone's fault, this was a PS2 game, but having graphics that are far more than the PS2's graphics actually really makes you notice this small nitpick of a detail to the point where it's actually kind of jarring. 

Many remasters try to just bring an old series up to today's standards with enhanced graphics and quality of life upgrades while trying it's best to keep the original game's experience as close as possible, but this remaster is less like those remasters. It isn't really here to preserve the experience you had with the original trilogy, but is more here to just introduce new players into the series, while also giving old and new players alike a new 4th game. There's nothing inherently wrong with this at all, it's just something worth noting to temper expectations for those that wanted to experience Vol. 1 through 3 like they did from the PS2 era while getting some updates to bring it up to more modern standards.

These are the issues I found with the remaster. Not to say there are no positives, in fact if the remasters were actually bad, I wouldn't actually put this as a recommended title. There are far more than enough forum posts and reviews talking about why this game is worth it, while I felt like there weren't enough talking about the issues with this. 

I know some of you are going to be baffled at this, a review that basically talks about all the negatives and skips all the positives of a game, while at the same time telling you that I do in fact recommend this game, and that's completely rational, in fact it'd be weirder if you weren't wondering why. This review isn't here to deter anyone from buying the game, in fact it isn't even here to convince people to buy it, the reason why I made this was because I want people to temper expectations when it comes to this remaster. 



TL;DR original Trilogy's difficulty changes affect more than you initially think it will. If you want a pristine, but slightly updated experience with Volumes 1 through 3 before you move on to the new Volume 4, then you might be a tiny bit disappointed. Also, this review was merely me wanting to note some negatives, I still recommend the game if you're a fan, please don't hate me, I'm really sensitive

37476140.review:
There are problems with this game, Dialogue can be stilted, awkward, and sometimes cringey. Plotholes show up if you dare to look up how this relates to any of the other series in dot hack. The story and characters will sometimes rely on tropes and archetypes and turn into melodrama a few too many times. Gameplay can get monotonous at times and collecting chims, symbols, etc can ruin the pacing of a dungeon.

I recognize this game has a lot of problems that don't make it an amazing game. And yet, I absolutely adore this game

I'm going to own up to my bias here, I played this as a teenager but never finished it back on the ps2 days. I never knew all that happened but I got far enough that I was captivated by the world. Art design, atmosphere, world building, and the feel of it all is so sublime that I have trouble properly wording it.
While the design can get ludicrous at times, it's such a varied and unique style that I've never encountered another game that has produced this weird combination of celtic/germanic fantasy and japanese style. The music hits you the best with this combination as you'll be quick to notice that it loves the german language to induce a very nice mysterious atmosphere at key moments. The cinematics also show off how this is when CyberConnect2 really started to embrace their insane animation style. It is a an absolute joy to watch and it sucks there aren't more hand animated cutscenes. Finally, the changes they made really fized the pacing of these games. Each game back in the day took 20+ hours and now the whole series has been condensed with each part being a nice 10-15 hour experience. It really is the first series (dot hack in general not G.U.) that popularized the idea of making a story take place in a real game, and G.U. is the best the series has to offer.

It's not a perfect game, but I am begging you to give it a chance, If you don't like it, that is completely fine, but I see so much potential for this series and I hope more people can see why I love it.

Coming from a newcomer's perspective into the .Hack series, .Hack//G.U. last recode is the first game I’ve played in the series so from this perspective I would like to say if you are a newcomer .Hack//G.U. last recode is a great introduction to the PS2 underrated game series that hopefully can be reborn into today's market. That said this game comes with all 3 volume's for the .Hack//G.U. trilogy with an extended volume 4 that adds a liner 3 hour or so expansion onto the story of the trilogy that overall helped finalise and gave a satisfying conclusion to this 100 hour or so story of a MMORPG that is a single player game..... Huh.

Some great things that this game does is that the overall story and characters are all interesting with some that you will love while some you will hate (won't say any names) that will make you keep coming back to see what happens in this game. Speaking of game the gameplay itself seems to improve as you go through the volumes with new battle techniques  being introduced as the volumes go on and for the most part the combat is fun and has a very 'tales of' action feel to it but just not as refined. 

However some things must be made apparent when dealing with .Hack//G.U. Last Recode as there are some cons I personally found with the game, the first thing is the keyboard control scheme seriously F.......k this default setup it is absolutely horrible and it doesn't help that the game's tutorial has only the Xbox controller prompts in the game so good luck finding out what A, X, B, Y, LB, LT ext. are because the game won't tell you that. But to be fair you can change the assigned key's in the options so that's a minor complaint I’m just warning anyone that plays this with a keyboard to find your own set-up like I had to. 

A final minor complaint is that while gameplay is fun for the most part there is a lot of grinding to do if you want get 100% in this game mainly with the side quests that are not only repeated across all the volumes but can be very annoying to say the least to complete. I mean the amount of times I had to kick Chim Chim's, save Mecha Grunty, hunt down Pk'ers, talk to people to hand out flyer's and kick mystic animals (please don't call PETA on me) are repeated throughout all of volume's 1 to 3, but you can ignore them if you want to.

I know this review may make it seem my experience with the game was repetitive and you could be right to an extent but honestly it does have a lot of fun moments and the story and characters are really good and I don't want to say anymore with the fear of spoiler's. For people who have never played it and are interested in .Hack//G.U. and I do highly recommend this game to newcomer's into the .Hack series as there is a lot of content to enjoy. However to those that have played the trilogy on your PS2 I personally would not recommend this to you, as from what I saw their really isn't anything new for you except vol 4 and a few updated cutscenes with better graphics but even then it doesn't justify a full price buy. So maybe wait for the price to come down and pick it up during a sale, overall anyone that is interested in story-rich games you will like what get here and this is a game that must be played.

37373138.review:
Nach über 100 Stunden Spielzeit und fast 100% Achievments, kann ich mir hoffentlich eine Meinung erlauben. 

Die Story: Die Geschichte von .Hack GU schließt nahtlos an den Anime an. Natürlich werden Leute die den Anime bereits gesehen haben, einen stärkeren Effekt genießen als die, die einfach nur mal ein .Hack-RPG ausprobieren wollten. Es ist zwar keine Pflicht den Anime zu schauen, da genügend Rückblenden und Erklärungen vorhanden sind, aber es ist trotzdem empfehlenswert. Die ersten paar Teile waren sehr langsam, und in jedem davon gibt es einen Arena-Abschnitt, welcher eine gute Abwechslung zum Monster-Gemetzel ist. Der dritte Teil aber hat mich vollends daran erinnert, warum ich einer der weniger Personen bin, welche über 18 ist und .Hack dem Anime SAO vorzieht - In jeglicher Hinsicht. Die Geschichte ist einfach brilliant, und hat sehr schöne Mindfuck stellen.

Das Gameplay(Kampf): Ist sehr von den alten .Hack Teilen abgeschieden. Es basiert mehr auf Action und Reaktion, als auf Taktik. Für die Einen mag das ganz gut sein, für die Anderen eher nervig. Zu viele Gegner mit einem Stunlock, und einem ziemlich hässlichen Geschrei, wenn sie Dich in der Luft über 3 Sekunden fliegen lassen, während Du nichts dagegen tun kannst. Dafür aber machen Feinde Spaß, welche viel HP haben, aber das klassische: Tank, Heiler DPS-Prinzip bieten. Meistens müsst Ihr damit rechnen, den Boss zu tanken, während ihr Atoli zum Beispiel heilen lässt. Das Spiel will eine Simulation eines MMOs sein, und macht viele Dinge richtig. Aber um ehrlich zu sein, hatte ich diese Immersion nur zu Beginn des Spiels. Nach Vol. 1 nie wieder. Lediglich die ganzen Anspielungen von G.U erinnerten mich daran, dass es sich hierbei um ein Online-Spiel handelt. 

Zudem sind die Gebiete recht unterschiedlich und ansehlich. Es herrscht sogar der Drang das Gebiet komplett zu erkunden, um noch ein Ausrüstungsteil zu bekommen, welches vielleicht eine bessere Eigenschaft besitzt. 

Audio(Musik und Synchro): Sehr angenehm. Während Du die Story verfolgt, tauchen hin und wieder sogar Vocals auf, die sehr schön und japanisch klingen. Die Musik passt sich sehr gut der Umgebung an, sprich: Nachts eher leise und ruhiger, Tags über lieblich usw. Die Synchro ist auch sehr gut gelungen. Atoli's Stimme finde ich persönlich sehr schön, auch wenn sie zu Beginn eher wie ein dummes Kind wirkt, was durch Ihre Vergangenheit aber Sinn macht, sollte man sich mehr mit den Charakteren befassen. 

PC-Port: Naja... Es geht. Ich hatte keine Ruckler, aber haufenweise Slow-Motion Effekte, die sicher ungewollt waren. Die Einstellungen der Optionen ist auch nicht wirklich gut, und der Support der Entwickler ist kaum vorhanden. Abstürze gab es meinerseits auch ein paar, aber seit kurzem nicht mehr. (Anscheinend wurde das behoben, obwohl ich keinen Download gesehen habe)

Fazit: Das Spiel wird dem niedrigen Metacritic-Score nicht gerecht. Es hat Höhen und Tiefen, aber es gibt kaum ein vergleichbares RPG auf dem Markt, welches sich für einen Vergleich anbieten könnte. Es wäre toll gewesen, wenn das Spiel einen Koop-Modus gehabt hätte, mit schwierigen Gebieten dessen Wörter man in der Kampanie freischalten muss, mit einem netten Endboss als Kirsche.

As soon as installed this game I bought some snacks, closed the blinds, I locked my door, I unpluged the modem, and isolated myself in my room for what felt like a full week. Todays games still take certain aspects from the .hack series and input these ideas into their games with a small modern twists, still creating inspiration' reminding people that this game series still stands to perfection time after time. Warp gates, Bike for fast movement, Weapon and armor grinding, CRIMSON VS, Goblin racing, Side quests, Post game after play and forums. 

The Soundtrack is God Tier and the people who made it deserve an award just in that one part of the game. (Nothing more I could Add.)

I look forward to seeing more of the .hack series with more to the combat. 
The fourth part needed a level cap raise and more monsters.
If you have a hoarding problem this game is not healthy for you.(I have one and i'm still somehow carrying gear from level 30 and below even though I dont need it, I know I could just sell it or discard it but I wont it will stay in my storage forever.

10/10 Story 
8.8/10 Combat
10/10 Game mechanics
10/10 Soundtrack
10/10 Application of use all together
S Grade

37095984.review:
I was given this game as a gift by a wonderful dear friend of mine, and I am deeply grateful for his charity as I wouldn't have been able to afford it otherwise.

When I was a teenager, .hack//G.U. changed my life. It is well and truly one of my favorite games of all time, one that I find is still dear to my heart after all these years. It is important to me in a way that few other games are - just because of the characters, who I resonated with on a personal level. The cast defies description, and I'd say, "just play the game yourself to see what they're like".
(To say that I was euphoric about the remaster would be an understatement. I have been annoying everyone I know about this game ever since I heard the news.)

That being said, as someone who played through the PS2 games entirely too much, I do have some qualms with this port. While I haven't experienced any of the legendary crashing issues, I have had framerate problems (though this may just be due to my admittedly lacking computer). Also, for those who are returning to the game from playing through it originally, there are some interface changes that may be confusing at first - in particular, the tab colors for "offline" and "online" party members have been switched, which still sort of disorients me.

All-in-all, though, I would still very much recommend this remaster. It's personal bias, but I still love this game with all of my heart, and the remaster, while flawed, has done it justice in my opinion.

37083062.review:
The .hack// series was one of my first video games that I truly loved. I looked forward to every day coming home from school to play this game. I didn't have a computer to find out about new installments at the time, so I was always looking for the next one in the series in my game stores. I can't explain the elation when I found one. I refreshed the store page on Steam multiple times a day waiting to pre-order. On the day of release, I came home at lunch and started its download. I left work early to come home and play. 37054257.review:
I have not played any of the .Hack games previoysly.

When i started the first volume, the gameplay was jarring and slow, it felt like there was something missing. I found almost everything from the first game annoying, but for some reason i couldn't stop playing. I finished Volume 1 in 2 days, with 24 hours of play time, and immediatly jumped into the second game.

It was when i got the ability to swap weapons by using skills mid-battle i found what was missing in the combat. it made the combat feel so much smoother and fun. Volume 2 was when i started to feel really fun PLAYING the game and not just the story.

Volume 3 was where everything really clicked into place when i unlocked 4th weapon type, and with 4 skill-slots i could swap between all of my weapons mid-combat. Combat feels really fluid and i'm really invested in the story. I'm still playing the Volume 3 even though i've finished the story about 4 hours ago when writing this review.

Biggest problem i have with these games is that they are a little too "shounen" for my taste, meaning that final battles are pretty much decided on who screams "OOOOOOOOOOOAAAAAAAAAOOOOOOHHHHHH" loudest and Gaspard is an annoying bitch, but he doesn't really appear in volume 2 & 3 so it's cool.

Largest suprise for me was the desktop system. I could check my characters email, check fake forums for the game, read fake news about whats happening in the games "real world", i could even go and download other "peoples" fan-arts about my and other characters.

I really enjoyed .hack//G.U. Last Recode, and i seriously hope that they remaster or remake the first 4 games.



Or even better: make new .hack// games.

37008739.review:
Côté positif: Ressortir une bonne trilogie de jeux ps2, c'est chouette. Espérer le retour d'une franchise qu'on apprécie aussi. La série des .Hack//GU est d'ailleurs une bonne entrée en matière dans la licence. Le gameplay est nettement plus fluide et dynamique que dans la première quadrilogie qui avait lancé l'univers sur console. Scénaristiquement, on a un bon développement du personnage principal au fil de l'intrigue et une représentation de MMO qui est tout de même plus intéressante que le jemenfoutisme d'un SAO (que je considère comme un harem correct mais une mauvaise franchise à ce niveau-là).

Côté négatif: J'ai vu pas mal de gens critiqué le port et, effectivement, il rame/bug facilement si on le laisse tourner avec les meilleures options graphiques. Après, sachant que c'est un jeu ps2, les baisser pour qu'il tourne normalement n'est pas une si grosse perte. L'augmentation des gains d'exp, des stats, etc. est également une idée moyenne. Certes, elle nullifie le besoin de farm, mais d'un autre côté elle rend le jeu trop simple à finir. Elle complique également la tâche pour tout compléter puisqu'elle force notamment à aller grinder son nombre de combats pour certains bonus cosmétiques après avoir atteint le niveau maximum.

Côté honnête: De toute façon, je suis fan et je finis mon badge des Steam Awards.

Besides the screen fading to black in the city of Mac Anu everytime I cross the bridge or some cheesy dialogue these games are pretty top notch in terms of content with tons of areas to explore (albeit you will be doing the same end goals for each area such as reach the treasure or kill the boss)  and enough side content to keep you busy! 36990501.review:
Im not gonna lie, my opinion of this game is probably biased because this game was my life for a period of time in 2008. But nostalgia doesn't always mean something is actually good. I still love it nonetheless. 
The game is highly story-driven and has an amazing soundtrack. But, with the remake they brought rebalancing and subsequently made the game too easy majority of the time. Avatar battles are still annoying tho. There is no point to the "cheat mode"  they added, its that easy normally.
As a game originally made for PS2 this port is fairly broken and clearly not optimized very well for PCs. Although there are many people who can run the game with out a hitch there are also many who have encountered a ton of problems with crashes and frame rate drops. (even some on high spec computers). Even when you can run the game fine, there are a lot of visual glitches I have encountered. 
You should expect to play this game with a controller as very little effort was made to make keyboard and mouse work for this game. The mouse pretty much has no function at all and the keyboard default binds make almost no sense. You must configure your controller through steam settings and they messed up with the binds for the d-pad so you'll probably have to go in a fix that but people have posted threads on the community forums to aid in that.
Also, as an HD "remaster",  the character models still look very clunky and the graphics are still very dated looking. It seems all they really did other than make it run at 60 fps and on higher resolution screens, is make the textures on models a little clearer. Definitely not on the same level as the remaster of the Kingdom Hearts games. But KH looked a lot better to begin with anyway. 
I am also fairly disappointed that they did not update pretty much any of the desktop wallpapers in the game to 1080p resolution, they just added an image border around the original image to make it fill out 1920x1080.
However, despite my complaints,  the games DO get better as you progress through the volumes, and although the game play is a little lacking, and the cut scene can sometimes really drag on for what feels like forever. Im really in it for the story, and I highly recommend the game and watching the related animes as well. The whole series has great music and an interesting story concept with good characters who actually have decent character development.

No. But the world .hack takes place in is so thorough and thought out that it is more immersive than any game I've ever played. Has the game aged well? not particularly, but the game is fun enough to overcome that. On top of this, the music, atmosphere, and extra content creates a depth and breadth you've likely never experienced in a game.

My recommendation:
If you want more information on the story watch a few episodes of .hack//roots on crunchyroll. It leads straight into the game, and will further build the world.

If you're up in the air on the gameplay, look up videos of arena fights. It will give you a better feel for the pacing of combat.

Finally, if you do decide to join the adventure I have this to say:

36894190.review:
Could not believe my eyes when I saw these 15-year-old gems being rereleased on PC and PS4. Enjoying this with my dad was such a big part of my childhood, and I am SOOOO excited to get back into it.

As I have put a few hours into it already, I can say for certain it feels exactly like it used to (with better graphics of course).

PROS:
-Updated graphics, much smoother and more pleasing than the originals.
-Soundtrack is phenominal, and most of the time it feels like it belongs in an actual MMORPG.
-While it can take some time to get used to, the main combat system is pretty tight, and knocking around enemies with big-ass weapons feels awesome.
-The important boss battles still feel very grand and spectacular.
-Loads and saves MUCH faster than it did on PS2, and runs very smoothly.
-Still feels immersive, even when not in the actual game. When not in "The World", the rest of the game exists on the computer desktop of the player behind the Haseo character. In a way, you effectively ARE that person.

CONS:
-Voice acting, as could be expected from the PS2 era, is rather cringy pretty often.
-As others have stated, the gameplay is pretty repetitive and linear. The 3rd game in the series did a bit better in this regard.
-The early hours of each game feel very limiting.
-Fairly low challenge (at least in Vol. 1), as the EXP grind was tuned down more than I thought.

Great JRPG, more enjoyable than most in my opinion. It has some faults but most of them come in the form of voice acting and (sometimes) low difficulty. I highly recommend to almost anybody, especially those looking for any of the following:

1.) a new single-player experience
2.) a positive entrance into the JRPG genre
3.) NOSTALGIA

36884388.review:
A nice port of some PS2 JRPG classics. While the visuals and gameplay are a bit dated (and a controller is required), the charm of the game still remains. 

Pros:
-A good, long story that takes place over several games.
-Satisfying combat, especially in the later volumes.
-A wide variety of areas.
-Often overlooked, but the music composed for this series is fantastic. It sounds amazing even today.

Cons:
-Graphics haven't aged well, even with this remastered version.
-Locked at 60 fps.
-XP changes have made the game a little bit too easy. 

Overall, this game is definitely worth it if you enjoy JRPGs. A huge amount of content is provided at your fingertips. It's great to be able to play .hack on PC after all of these years!

Огромное спасибо BANDAI NAMCO и CyberConnect2 за то что они сделали этот ремастер для персональных компьютеров. И за то, что позволили снова насладиться хорошей игрой в хорошем качестве. А так же, увидеть продолжение историии.

Про саму игру не буду особо распинаться, она не каждому понравится, но найдёт своего игрока. Лично мне эта серия очень нравится ещё со времён PS2. В ней есть неплохой сюжет (хотя в этой части, конечно, слегка уступающий первой квадрологии), прекрасная музыка, хорошие и разные персонажи и не совсем стандартная для игр тема про игру в игре, да к тому же про ММО.

К технической стороне у меня тоже никаких претензий нет. Картинка красивая и качественная, ничего не тормозит и не лагает, багов и вылетов не замечено.

PS: немного обидно, конечно, что не порадовали русским переводом, хотя в том же God Eater'е он имелся. Но это мелкое неудобство, не мешающее снова погрузиться в любимый мир .hack//.

36638685.review:
This being an HD remaster of ps2 era games, its probably not for everyone. I was a fan of the original .hack games, and surprisingly hadnt even heard GU existed until maybe a year ago so it was a "Duh" purchase the moment this was released.

Would I recommend this, even for non fans of the series? Definitely. Buy it. Now. Or wait for a sale, buy it twice, and gift the copy to someone. K, Its not THAT amazing, but I liked it alot. In comparison to the original 4, I feel that the story is much more involved and overall better, but as far a gameplay mechanics go I think they dropped the ball in a few spots:

1. Combat system is much more fluid. Thats a bonus, but as you progress through the volumes you get different forms that allow you to use more weapons. By the time I got to the end of 2 and around the middle of 3 I realized its almost pointless to use anything other than dual swords as your primary weapon. Everything else is just slow, until Xth.

2. There is a victory scene after every regular fight that you cannot skip. They build up your annoyance after playing the game for hours on end trying to grind to a certain level. The only way to avoid that is to get to volume 3, which by then its probably been over 40 hours...little late.

3. Combat difficulty is...low. At the start of every volume, if you level up 10-20 levels (and that doesnt take long), literally the rest of the volume is a cakewalk. Basically enemies below a certain threshold simply dont do damage to you, and your damage counter ramps up to 9999 just to show you how OP you are for that current area.

4. AI of party members is borderline mentally handicapped. Its been a while since I played the original 4, but it felt like you could tell your members what to do with a little more detail. In GU theres only 4 commands, and healing is the one I had the most issue with. You set a party member to heal and they about vanish from the battlefield and blow through their magic just to heal you for every speck of dirt that damages you, yet ignore people who die.

5. Activating story progression is the most tedious thing you will ever do. The game forces you to check your email for one message, to then have you log back in, change servers, warp to some 3 to 4 layer dungeon that you have to go to the end to for a 20 second cutscene that has -86% impact on anything, to then repeat it all for actual progression...

6. Status ailments arent so well defined as they were in the first 4. I didnt care enough to look it up, or pay close attention if it tells you in game, but I still have no idea what curse does. They also dont seem to affect enemies very much but will just about annihilate you without proper armor effects/items.

I can give all of those a pass for the most part considering the game's age, the reason I consider them cons is because I'm comparing them too much to modern games. Playing through these was a fun time killer, especially for a branch of the series I hadnt actually played before. There is an anime that is a prelude to this, which I have yet to watch. You wont be lost if you dont watch it, but it will explain a few key parts.

Its interesting to note that in Vol. 4 Reconnection, Piros lets slip that a new version of the world is coming. After realizing that Piros wasn't mandatory to talk to like the other party members and therefore easy to miss, along with the fact that Vol. 4 is brand new, It would be fun to imagine a modern entry to "The World" at some point in the future.

36602266.review:
I have 100% the first volume and getting ready to play again. Hello, I'm the "Prophet".

.hack//G.U. Last Recode is an beloved game with a story that rightfully is one of the best out there. I remember this game from my childhood, and it's still downright fun. This is a MUST-GRAB game to anyone who needs a new single-player game. To newcomers, I recommend reading (or play the original .hack video game) the first full series to better understand Kite's role. I'll list the pro/con, and I highly recommend this game, if it was not clear.

Pros
60 FPS for most of the game
Unique Characters and EXECELLENT storyline
An array of items to collect in all series
Does not crash often
Side-Quests that ACTUALLY are enjoyable (all but one)
Progress carries over to Volume 2, 3, and 4 (100% ACTUALLY MEANS SOMEHTING FOR ONCE)
Easily over 200+ hours of gameplay

Cons
The dreaded "White Screen Freeze", even if solution is simple
Even at a high difficulty, it's still somewhat easy
Grinding to 50 on Volume 1 is a cakewalk
Party members sometimes block you in
Trading system is easy to abuse and get high-level gear
Bikman's Flyer Side-Quest is the most RNG-painful experience you'll have in Volume 1

In spite of my cons, I enjoy this game as I move on to Volume 2.
Buy this game.
Trust me.

36597377.review:
What you need to know:
This game is 100% story-driven.
Combat is extremely simple.
The game operates or a strict formula.
The main character has decent character growth but it takes a while for him to become likable.

Pro: The game does a great job of making you fill like your apart of the world. Small touches like the using the main character's desktop, watching newsreels or reading posts was really immersive and unique.

Con: This game has a extremely repetive formula which it vehemently sticks to. Here's what it looks like: Watch a Cutscene, Go speak to someone, Go on a quest with that person, Finish that quest and they tell you something, Log out of game and check your email. Rinse wash repeat.

Honestly I've enjoyed the game but I think $30 is a bettter price, I say this because there isn't much to game it's self beyond the story and it can feel a bit repetitive. That being said I can see why this game has some nostalgia attached to it because it's definitely a solid PS2 game.

36585300.review:
[b]Note[/b]: Posting this review after finishing vol. 1, might update later.

[u]Vol. 1[/u]:
Summary:
Classic PS2 JRPG with a fairly engaging story, though game is left marred by slightly weak gameplay and level design when compared to other similar JRPGs of the era.

Pros:
+ Fun yet simple combat
+ Great story with well thought out characters and storylines for each
+ Plenty of content on offer and plenty of things to do
+ SImplistic yet charming artstyle
+ Great character designs
+ Avatar battles are pretty awesome (much better than the main combat IMHO)

Cons:
- Three different level types that don't have many permutations to distinguish each dungeon. Gives game a repetitive feel at times.
- Although fun, combat isn't very mechanically deep, challenging or well balanced. Didn't die or come close to dying once.

Mixed:
-/+ Apart from a few standouts, music is servicable but unmemorable
-/+ Levelling is kind of fast. Whilst this means you don't spend nearly as much time in repetitive dungeons/fields, this does give you less chance to smell the roses if that's what you want.

Overall probably about a 7/10 for the first volume.

After all the positive reviews i got this over SAO... i am very disappointed. I have no problems with the outdated presentation (I love Trails in the Sky) but the game itself is not very interesting. It's not the worst game, but it's not a very good one too.. After playing Tales of Berseria and Trails in the Sky this game seems just very very flat.

36546984.review:
Port is fine, make sure you turn Vsync off or you will have lag issues. The same is true for all games. The only "issue" is that the PS4 buttons are not the displayed buttons, but being on Windows, where the main controller is the Xbox controller, it's reasonable to expect that it's the supported controller. 

As for people saying this is too easy, yeah, it sorta is. This wasn't meant to have the same feel. It was meant to get new players into the series and test the waters to see if people were still interested in this series. They're already working on another game, but this one will probably determine if IMOQ is remade. 

Without making this too long, stop having modern-day expectations on a game that was made 15 years ago, and it's a perfectly fine game. It's a remaster, not a remake. It's mostly graphical updates with some gameplay tweaks. If you want to have higher expectations, have the expectations on the new game they're making. This is a 15 year old game ffs. Can't expect stellar quality outside the story and gameplay style.

36533145.review:
Vorab sollte ich sagen, dass ich die ersten .hack Teile damals auf der PS2 geliebt habe und soweit ich mich erinnere, wir in Deutschland nie die Chance hatten, die G.U. Teile zu zocken. Dementsprechend habe ich es nicht erwarten können, mich hieran versuchen zu können!

Positiv: 
- STORY!
Das wird immer einer der stärksten Punkte in .hack sein. Die Story hat alles, was man sich wünschen kann: Drama, ein paar gute Lache, interessante Charaktere. Ich hatte am Anfang bedenken, da das Spiel sowohl ohne Kite, als auch ohne Black Rose und andere bekannte Charaktere aus den ersten Teilen auskommt. Zumindest als wirklich relevante Story Charaktere. Ich bin jetzt im zweiten Game und fand den Storyverlauf wirklich super!
Die Story ist auch der EINZIGE Grund, wieso ich dieses Spiel empfehlen kann. 
- Transferiberbarer Spielstand
Wenn du ein Spiel durch hast, kannst du deinen erfahrenen Haseo auf das neue Game übertragen. Finde ich prima, da man so das Gefühl hat, dass man auch wirklich weiter spielt und nicht alles verliert, was man mühsam zusammen gehamstert hat.
- kein grinden
Dazu äußere ich mich bei den negativen Punkten, aber es gibt ja Leute, die hassen es stundenlang durch Dungeons zu heizen und EP zu farmen. Was die Japaner auch annehmen, was vermutlich auch der Grund für die EP Anpassung gewesen ist. 
- schönes Remake
Grafisch ist es natürlich kein Witcher 3, aber ich finde das gerade die richtigen Sequenzen sehr schön aussehen und wer auf den Anime Stil steht, der wird hier auch auf seine Kosten kommen.
- viel Spiel, für wenig Geld
Also drei Games plus DLC... ich bin jetzt 33 Stunden dabei und am Anfang von Game 2. Gut, ich musste einige Dungeons wiederholen wegen den crashes aber nun ja. 

Negativ:
- Crashes ZU HAUF
Zum Glück gibt es auf Steam einige versierte Nutzer, weswegen ich als Windows 10 Nutzern den heftigsten Crash Wellen entgegen wirken konnte, allerdings kommen Crashes DENNOCH regelmäßig vor. Was nicht mal schlimm wäre...
-.... wenn man in Dungeons speichern könnte: Ohne Mist, man bräuchte das nicht, wenn das Spiel zuverlässig laufen würde, aber mir ist es jetzt schon OFT passiert, dass das Game einfach random abstürzt und ich den Dungeon einfach komplett von vorne spielen darf. 
-Sehr leichter Schwierigkeitsgrad
Wenn ich an die ersten Teile denke, kommt mir vor allem der knackige Schwierigkeitsgrad in den Sinn. Was hab ich Kite und Black Rose durch die Dungeons prügeln müssen, damit ich die teilweise echt schwierigen Bosse besiegen kann. Damals, jung und unerfahren wie ich war, bin ich irgendwann auch nicht mehr weiter gekommen. Das gibt es hier nicht, da man unglaublich schnell Erfahrung sammelt und sobald man ungefähr 3-5 Level über den Monstern ist, man diese mit zwei Schlägen weghaut. Umgekehrt kann man aber auch in Dungeons gehen, die locker 15-20 Level über einem sind, ohne das man fürchten muss, dass man drauf geht. Da ist es wahrscheinlicher, dass die Crashes dich killen. 
Es hatte schon fast etwas amüsantes, wenn man im ersten Game in dem Turnier ist und man ANGEBLICH besiegt wird, obwohl der SUPERANGRIFF des gegenübers kaum schaden macht. 
Ich bin jetzt am Anfang des zweiten Games. Im ersten Game war der Max Level 50, sodass ich mit diesem auch angefangen habe. Die ersten Story Dungeons sind level 43. Dementsprechend langweilig ist der Einstieg, da ich davon AUSGEGANGEN bin, dass die Dungeons sich bei einem übertragenen Spielstand anpassen würden. Sprich schwieriger sind. Dem ist aber nicht so. Und ich habe echt keine Dungeons nebenher gemacht, nur die Nebenquests und das, was man so in diesen Foren findet. Aber es ist nicht notwendig, in den Games zu grinden um voran zu kommen. Mir persönlich gefällt das nicht so, da das für mich einen großen Reiz des .hack Gameplays hat. 
- Etwas eintönig
Hat mich sonst nicht gestört, da ich gegrindet habe und mich jedes Level ungemein erfreut hat. Es gab kein Open End und du konntest von Level zu Level gehen, um besser zu werden. Jetzt wirken die Level eintönig, die Dungeons sind immer gleich aufgebaut und auch das, was man dort tun muss, ist immer gleich. Auch die Nebenquests sind genauso eintönig gemacht, nur die amüsanten Nebenstorylines sind es wert das zu machen. 
- Wahl der Synchronstimmen
Heilige Maccaroni, die Stimme von dieser Atoli tötet meine Ohren. Die Stimmen sind meistens gut gewählt. Haseo dürfte Naruto Fans bekannt vorkommen (ich spreche von der englischen Variante), da er der Sprecher von Sasuke ist. Die Kampfgeräusche von Pi gehen mir zwar auf die Nerven, kann man aber ertragen. Aber Atolis englische Stimme... alter Verwalter. 

Trotz der vielen negativen Punkte, würde ich mir G.U. DENNOCH noch mal kaufen. Denn ich habe weiter gespielt, trotz der crashes, trotz der nervigen Atoli und trotz eintönigem Gameplay. Die Story übertönt das ganze und es ist unheimlich viel Nostalgie dabei, wenn ich .hack spiele. Die Idee des MMOs ist einfach super umgesetzt und es macht Spaß, wenn Haseo zum gefühlten 10000sten mal sagt, dass er sich ausloggen und seine Mails checken möchte. Auch, dass man auf manche E-Mails und Foreneinträge antworten kann, gibt einem das Gefühl, tatsächlich Haseo zu sein und dieses Online Game zu spielen.

36527602.review:
Unfortunately, when I was younger I never had the chance to get into the .hack games.  Years down the road I played the G.U series on an emulator.  Now, several years later, I was fortunate enough to see this remake come out on steam.  I love .hack for its story and the G.U. series does not disappoint.  IMO the story was quite interesting, I enjoyed the character development that happens throughout the series, and compared to the original series, G.U. felt very polished by comparison.  This remake takes something that was already wonderful and made it even better.

     If you are new to .hack or at least the G.U. series.  I would suggest watching the .hack roots anime.  If you don't like anime or have time to watch it, you can still very much enjoy and understand the events in this game as they touch on past events that were important anyway.  The game is set up to simulate a real computer environment.  You have "the world" (the name of the MMO being played in the .hack series), your e-mail, online news and forums, etc.  All of this helps to set the tone for the game as well as create the actual world you are playing in.  You actually roleplay the person that is playing an MMORPG.
     
     There are several random NPC characters running around that act as simple player characters.  You can talk to them, trade with it, and gift them items as you would expect to be able to do with players in an MMO.  You party with various characters and go on quests and explore dungeons, as you might expect to do in an MMO.  I was actually quite surprised how far they went to make it feel that you were a person communicating with other players online and playing an MMO with them.  Now, is it completely realistic or a perfect simulation of this?  Of course not!  However, it does the job and does it quite well.  Read the news articles and forum posts as you progress throughout the game to see what is going on in the world, some events being a direct result of things happening in the MMO.

     .Hack was truely ahead of its time.  Perhaps to it's detriment.  Hopefully it will see a bit of a revival as the "trapped in an MMO" thing has grown in popularity the last couple years.  If you have the money, you don’t mind playing a single player game, and you want something fun with active combat (this is not turn based), a decent story that is pretty well told, something that feels larger than the game itself, and actually has character development (yes it exists) then try this game out especially if you are a fan of anything .hack!

These two factors completely remove ANY challenge from the game.

36518668.review:
Great game(s), but needs some patches.
---

Growing up, I was a huge fan of the .hack//SIGN anime and the original games. I never played the PS2 .hack//G.U. games, so I was very excited to see them remastered, and have the chance to log back into The World. 

The 'world' of .hack// is immense. That being said, if you aren't familiar with the franchise, this game makes it easy to enter into the series. The "Terminal Disc" included also provides a synopsis of the original .hack// games (usually referred to as .hack//IMOQ), if you weren't able to play them when they originally released. Even so, that information is still background, and won't hinder your experience if you don't watch. I have been supplementing my gameplay by watching the .hack//SIGN series again, then the Terminal Discs, and now .hack//Roots (an anime that takes place right before G.U. actually begins).

I'm currently working on Vol.1, so not sure how this will change, but so far I am enjoying the game. The characters are all memorable; most are cliché, but in a way that remains humorous. Some users have complained about the game being too easy (esp. those who played G.U. on PS2); while I cannot advise on the difference, I have found that often the combat is not difficult, unless encountering enemies that are quite higher in level. I don't have an issue with the pace of leveling, although the Weapon Skill leveling (separate from Character Level) isn't as transparent as it could be. 

Something that I have always enjoyed about the .hack games is the 'meta' game. The MMO where most of the action occurs, "The World," is just one aspect of the actual game - you also have access to the Official and Community Forums, News Site, and Email. In essence, you're playing the person who is playing the character of Haseo. While this adds to the immersion, it can occasionally become inconvenient - for example, after reaching a certain point in the area, in order to progress, you have to Log Out, check your email to see that you've qualified for the next step, and then you can log back in and proceed. 

It is worth noting that there are some issues with this port, which hopefully the developers will patch soon. This game is clearly made to be played with a controller, but it only has Xbox controls native (odd given that steam supports DS4 controller, and the game is originally from PS2 and has a PS4 port). There are some mods which address this, but it's unfortunate that it wasn't included. Many people encountered issues with the 'anti-aliasing.' I personally play on a laptop not geared towards high-end gaming, so I had to decrease the resolution, but once done was able to get consistent 60fps. 

I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys JRPGs, people who are interested in learning more about the .hack franchise, and definitely to those who are longtime fans of the series.

36505700.review:
Pros

+ The single-player MMO gimmick is one of it's best features. You can read and respond to emails sent by your companions, read up on current events in the dot hack universe through the news system, play a  pretty decent card game or read the game's many forums and respond to some of the topics. Some of the banter in the forums was top notch.
+ Pretty decent story that flows well through all four volumes. 
+ Memorable characters, most of the characters get a good amount of development throughout the games. Either through in game cinematics or emails.
+ The combat is pretty good, similar to 'Tales of' action RPGS.
+ The restored textures look great and for a PS2 era game it aged very well.
+ Lengthy game (if you are playing all 4 volumes for the first time). There is a lot to do in each volume besides the main story. 
+ Soundtrack was excellent, and the voice acting ( I played with the Japanese dub) was solid.
+ Good port, had no real issues worth mentioning. Assuming you don't have a toaster you should be able to run this fine.

Cons

- While the majority of the cast is pretty great there a few characters (GASPARD!!!!) that are insufferable. The main character, Haseo, falls into this category for most of the first game. Thankfully he grows out of it later. Same could be said for Atoli.
- Do not go into this game expecting a complex dungeon crawler with an amazing combat system. One of the game's biggest issues is its repetitive nature. 
- This is especially prevalent with the dungeon/quest design. You will get very sick of seeing this one cave dungeon that the developers just love to use for so many of the quests and side quests over and over again. To add to that most of the story missions are set in the worst most repetitive and boring dungeons (out of the 8 or so dungeons styles there are in the game).
- The boss battles and overall difficulty of the game is pretty low. I never found a need to grind other than to raise my level enough to use certain weapons that I acquired. The game is very easy, there were a handful of moments were I felt pressured and that was mostly due to not bringing a dedicated healer (Atoli) or purposefully fighting bosses several levels higher than me. 
- The crafting/upgrading system was pretty meh. I hardly ever used it or had need for it.


Overall, I got 73 hours out of this game. Not bad for a $50 game. Finally got a chance to play a series I never had the opportunity to play back when it was relevant. Hopefully, Cyberconnect2 will take a break from making Naruto games and go back to making a new .hack series. There's a bit of a 4th wall breaking tease at the end of vol.4 by the amazing Piros the 3rd. Make sure to talk to him at the end of the game.

36493865.review:
[b]TLDR: These games are okay.  Conditional Recommend, but I would wait for a sale.[/b]

After playing through the first game, I've got to say I'm a little disappointed.  The biggest impression that the game left on me is "this looks cheap."  There are very few areas, the graphics are not great (even for 2006), the gameplay is mashy and not difficult, and the story (at least at the end of volume 1) really smacks of stuff I've seen a hundred times.  Maybe this was a big thing back when .hack was new, but this was still many years after Ultima Online, Everquest, even World of Warcraft.  MMO's weren't really that mysterious...

I guess my biggest problem with the game is how many other fantastic RPGs were on PS2 for years before this game came out, which leads me to my conclusion that this game feels really cheap.  I could probably list a couple dozen PS2 games which were better in all ways than these and came out before.  When you stack it next to games like Grandia, Dark Cloud, Tales of Symphonia, SMT: Nocturne, Shadow Hearts, FF12, and Persona 3, it falls flat on its face.  It just seems [i]really uninteresting[/i].

(Man I would love a modern release of Shadow Hearts and Shadow Hearts: Covenant... I wonder who has the rights nowadays.)

I know those two paragraphs make me sound like I'm down on the game, but I'm really not.  It's an okay game, but if I knew before what I know now I wouldn't have paid full price for it.  So I say if you're into .hack this version is pretty good, but if you're a new player I would wait for a sale.

36475660.review:
Having played the original trilogy on PS2 back in the day (played through both volume 1 and 2 and most of volume 3), it was an understatement to say I was excited for Last Recode and had high expectations of it. And I am happy to say that the majority of those expectations were either met or exceeded. But before I go into all my positives of the game so far (Note I have only 100% the first volume so far) let's quickly go over the negatives before the positives.

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*]This PC port had its fair share of issues when I was trying to play the game at the start, such as the game not using the right graphics card or the fact that the game would crash like 10 minutes in until I was able to fix said issue by turning off some background program in Windows. So needless to say, it was a real pain trying to play this game.
[*]Also in terms of some of the changes they made, I feel that they really should have included a harder difficulty mode because with the increased exp gain and whatnot, it is really easy to get over-leveled in the game early on and as a result I had to solely focus on the main story stuff for quite a while until the levels caught up to me. 
[*]Some might find the game to be lacking in the visual department since despite it being an HD remaster,the look hasn't changed too much from the original PS2 games.
[*]Finally, just like the original trilogy, the game's tutorial goes on for way too long and it also likes to railroad you into following the plot rather than just letting you do your own thing early on, which is annoying. Also in said tutorial, they use the term 'noob' way too much, which is aggravating to say the least.

[*][i]PS: I hate Gaspard and Bikman's flyer quest.[/i]
[/list]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*]I find the combat to be rather simple, but still quite enjoyable. The enemies offer a reasonable level of challenge as long as you aren't over-leveled and there are a variety of enemy types that keep the battles from getting too monotonous.
[*]I still love how the dungeons are made with choosing three key words from a list in order to decide the type of difficulty. It's just such a fun concept and the fact that you get rewarded more key words by completing dungeons and visiting the forums just make its even better.
[*]Speaking of the forums, the main menu when you are not logged into the game is probably one of my favorite parts since you just get to see what's going on in the world, get to hear what you're fellow npc characters in the game are up to, and in general I feel it really nails the feeling of playing an online game.
[*]I ended up loving almost all of the characters as the story develops and Haseo's story really just pulls you in and makes you want to see how he develops along with his fellow players and goes from a character who resembles Sasuke from the Naruto series, to how I wish Sasuke ended up.
[*]Also the music in this game is pretty great and the voice acting for the dub at least is mostly stellar with a few exceptions.
[/list]
Overall, despite the problems mentioned above, I really love this game series and cannot wait to 100% the rest of the game. And to all those who are even remotely interested in giving this series a shot, I would definitely recommend taking the plunge because it is truly a game series worth playing.

36469644.review:
>>>Mostly spoiler free<<<
Only spoils are estimates on how long the game would take 



TL;DR if you're wanting to play all the games, you can expect about 80 hours of content (Not counting the longer grinds). But it's not worth it just for the 4TH game.


If you want to play just the NEW GAME, don't bother. It's only about two or three hours tops. They even literally disable al lthe side content and even though they updated the models to look more modern (Only in this game for some reason?), only having like two dungeons to run that are both generic is pretty boring. There's no side missions, no events, no special thing you can do. Just a short epilouge plot that expands on the lore some and ties up loose ends kind of nicely. They even got most (or all?) of the old voice actors for returning characters, so the voices soudn fine.

New game aside, the old games were HD'd in a nice way that doesn't take away from them, but it's also pretty clear it's just HD'd PS2 games, so the models themselves look old; but they overall hold up decently since thanks to a lot of care being put into them back when they were first made; you'll just notice hair clipping or blocky hands outside of cutscenes.. A lot of clear love was put into it to make sure it all translated well. I dind't have any major issues with the games, Only crashed once in over 80 hours, No audio desync issues (in the first three games anyway), everything functions the same, and the games actually hold up fairly well when compared to modern games. There's plenty of secrets to find, optional grind quest with fun little rewards but nothing mandatory, the games can be as hard as you make them (if you just do story it can be pretty hard, but it's easy to go and out grind them to easily breeze through the story).


If you're looking for a really long game experience and want a game that looks pretty nice and is fairly actiony without much filler plot, this is a decent game to pick up. It's got multiple twist and turns ot the story with a pretty deep and complex world where they actually took the time to make fake forum post by people, even having a bunch of random artist make art for the game so people on the forums could post their own art in various different styles. They made anime news videos to look like actual news reporters talking to you about stuff, and a decently long news series where you kind of get to see how people in the real world respond to stuff going on in your game world (and see what the effects are, it gives nice context to what you're doing).


Honestly what befudles me is how the New game had them go through the trouble of updating all the models of characters you don't get much time with and making them look nice, but they didn't just put that in the older games and left those mostly un touched. The new game mostly just plays the same as the old ones. You eventually get the New Form you see on the cover art, and it has a clear amount of love put into it with very unique attacks and combos that are a ton of fun to watch and use.... but again, the new game is so short and you don't have any areas to really go and enjoy it.


Hopefully we'll see more from this series, I'd love it if .hack made some big comeback, and it does kind of hint that there's possibilities for a new story to start, but I'm finding it really unlikely as of right now.

[u][i]*คำเตือน* เนื้อหาในบางส่วนอาจจะมีมุกแป้กและคำพูดฮาๆ ปนอยู่บางเล็กน้อย หากใครไม่ชอบ ผมขออภัยมา ณ ที่นี้ด้วยครับ[/i][/u]

หลังจากเกิดเหตุการณ์ไฟไหม้ตึกของบริษัทที่สร้างเกม The World (The World R:1 ของภาค .hack) จึงทำให้ Server ข้อมูลสำคัญหลักเสียหายอย่างหนัก บริษัทจึงได้ปิดให้บริการไป ต่อมาทางบริษัทได้สร้างเกม The World ขึ้นมาใหม่เป็น The World R:2 ขึ้นมา เป็นจุดเริ่มต้นก้าวเข้าสู่ .hack//G.U. นั่นเอง....... (ไม่จำเป็นต้องเล่นภาค .hack มาก่อนก็สามารถสนุกกับภาคนี้ได้ครับ)

[u][b]เกริ่นนำเนื้อเรื่องก่อนเข้าสู่ช่วงเนื้อเรื่องหลักของเกม[/b][/u] ตัวเอกของเราซึ่งเป็นผู้เล่นหน้าใหม่แห่ง The World R:2 นามว่า Haseo (Ha-se-o) เพิ่งจะได้เข้ามาเล่นเกมเป็นครั้งแรก ก็ถูกผู้เล่นคนอื่น 2 คนที่ดูเหมือนนิสัยใจดี เข้ามาช่วยสอนวิธีพื้นฐานในการเล่นเกมให้ พอถึงจุดหมายสำคัญของดันเจี้ยน ปรากฏว่าผู้เล่น 2 คนนั้นคือ Player Killer (PK) นั่นเอง Haseo ได้ถูกจัดการลงและได้รับการช่วยเหลือจาก Ovan ชายปริศนาที่แขนข้างซ้ายมีลักษณะแปลกๆ เวลาผ่านไป 8 เดือน Haseo ได้แข็งแกร่งขึ้นมากและผันตัวเองขึ้นมาเป็น PKK (Player Killer Killer หรือ นักฆ่า PK) มีฝีมือโหดมากๆ จนได้รับฉายาว่า "Terror of Death (ความพรั่นพรึงแห่งมรณา)" และตอนนั้น Haseo กำลังออกตามหา PK ปริศนา นามว่า "Tri-Edge" เพราะเมื่อ 6 เดือนก่อน Tri-Edge เป็นคนสังหาร Shino เพื่อนสนิทสาวคนสำคัญของ Haseo ส่วน Shino คนในโลกแห่งความเป็นจริงตกอยู่ในสภาพโคม่า ไม่สามารถฟื้นขึ้นมาได้ จนในที่สุด Haseo ก็เจอ Tri-Edge และได้ต่อสู้อย่างเต็มกำลัง แต่ก็ไม่สามารถทำอะไร Tri-Edge ได้เลยแม้แต่รอยแมวข่วน [spoiler](โธ่ววววว กากจริงๆ ถถถถถถ)[/spoiler] ทาง Tri-Edge ได้โต้กลับยิงลูกพลังงานปริศนาใส่ Haseo ทำให้ Haseo ตัวสลายหลุดออกจากเกมไปราวเหมือนกับตัวประกอบยังไงอย่างงั้น และจากเลเวล 133 กลายเป็นเลเวล 1 อีกทั้งข้อมูลต่างๆที่เก็บไว้หายไปหมดด้วยเช่นกัน [spoiler]ทำให้พระเอกของเราโครตเงิบเป็นอย่างมาก[/spoiler] หลังจากนั้นก็เข้าสู่เนื้อเรื่องหลักของเกมแล้วครับ ประกอบไปด้วย เต่า[spoiler](มิตรภาพ)[/spoiler] มาม่า[spoiler](ดราม่า)[/spoiler] หัวร้อน[spoiler](เคียดแค้น)[/spoiler] โลกเป็นสีชมพู[spoiler](รักๆใคร่ๆ)[/spoiler] ที่ใช้อุ่นซาลาเปา[spoiler](ฉากซึ้งๆ)[/spoiler] รวมไปถึงมีบทสนทนาตลกๆแฝงในเกมไว้บ้าง

36438796.review:
I'm so sad. I love this series so much, the nostalgia alone from the opening cutscenes gives me chills. Seeing it remastered in HD is literally a wet dream come true.

However, this is a poor port (as of right now). The game on its base settings moves VERY slow. The cutscene's, dialog, movement all look like they've been set to 1/2 speed. I have tried adjusting the settings after doing some comment digging. Turning off shadows, anti-aliasing and playing in windowed bordeless mode on 1280 x 720 does infact fix the 1/2 game speed issue. The game will run smooth as butter after that, but you end up sacraficing (at least I do) a large unused portion of your pc screen.

For how big a fan I am I was willing to make that sacrafice for overall playability.

Now here comes the dealbreaker. The crashes.

This port REGULARLY crashes during cutscenes. The good news is it isn't consistent from what i've experienced (it never just walled and crash during one specific part of a cutscene or dialog), but thats also bad news all the same. You never know when it will crash, or when the crash is coming. You just know it will be during a cutscene if it does, and not all cutscenes seem to trigger a crash. 

To add salt to the wound, the way this game is set up, you do not have the capability to save in the middle of "Areas" (or dungeons if you want to call them that). You can save either before or after leaving an area. Area's (not all of them but mandatory ones needed to progress the stoy) have cutscene's! So imagine running 2/3rds of an Area just for the game to crash during a cutscene at the end of it. With no way to save mid Area, you have to literally restart the game, and repeat the area- in the hopes the cutscene wont trigger the crash, with no garuntee.

...And well you see, the way my bank account is set up- REFUND!

P.S. In all honesty this would be a 10/10 for me if the bugs are fixed. Fix the 1/2 speed game issue, and fix the crash issue. My fear is that, as i've seen with a lot of ports- they get released and essentially forgotten, with either ridculous wait times for patches to be rolled out, or no patches ever being released at all.

I'm STILL waiting for Nier to be patched to working status.

I get this was barely added to steam, so I'm not that upset- but I will be refunding this and checking in to see if/when a patch rolls out to fix these issues. Then I will definitely buy this again in a heartbeat.

36437462.review:
I'm closing in on the end of Vol. 1 of the game, so I'll add more to this review as I progress.

First, I have to say this: I've been a fan of the .hack series since the first four games came out on PS2, so I may not be an impartial critic of this remaster.  Then again, you might want the opinion and analysis of someone who's played the games since the beginning.

That aside, from what I've seen, this is an excellent remaster.  Visuals have been cleaned up, animations look far smoother than they ever were on the PS2, audio is crisp, camera moves smoothly as well... pretty much what you'd expect a good remaster to do is done here.  It's a solid HD port.

This is one game that you'll want to play on a controller, though.  Not saying that it's going to be difficult with K+M, but if you want to get the full experience from when the G.U. games were on PS2, you'll want to get a gamepad for your computer.  It feels more intuitive, I guess.  Aside from that, controls are fine.

Combat is the same as it was on the PS2, so if you've played the G.U. Trilogy on PS2 or on an emulator, there won't be any difference with the combat itself, aside from some changes done by Bandai Namco to make the games easier for newcomers.

Speaking of which, there are a number of minor changes that make the game easier, both with general QoL as well as in combat.  Haseo's running speed is significantly faster than it was in the PS2 games, making traversing dungeons and larger fields feel like less of a chore.  You can carry 90 items and 90 pieces of equipment from the beginning, rather than starting with 30 and upgrading through the volumes as you play them.  You can also carry 99 of each consumable/mod item, so chances are that with some minor inventory management, you'll never run out of room.  This makes trading considerably easier, because you'll have more throwaway items to trade towards equipment and items you want (which is really helpful with the Book of 1000 sidequest).  You can also hold up to 999 Chim Spheres, whereas in the original games you couldn't hold any more than 99 (this makes dealing with Steam doors and the Mecha Grunty sidequest SOOOOOOO MUCH EASIER).

I believe there are also some changes to how much damage Haseo and his party can do to enemies, and the Avatar battles have been made somewhat easier by increasing the damage from Skeith's shots.  Besides that, if you do die in battle, the game gives you the option to retry that fight (which was not in the PS2 games).  This is to avoid the problem of having to reload a previous save, which is helpful if you haven't saved for some time.  However, with certain random encounters (particularly the Chaotic PKs for the Bounty Hunter sidequest), it potentially means you're stuck in a fight with an enemy that can kill you in one or two hits if you're too low in level, and you'll either have to spend a lot of time trying to win a tough fight or just reload from your last save.  This can be problematic.  Of course, since this is an RPG, you should be saving regularly anyway.  :P  Speaking of saving and loading, it goes by in a flash; the PS2 versions had periods between cutscenes and transitioning from field to root towns where it could load for up to a couple of minutes, and saving took several seconds.  Now there's none of that.

Aside from this, I've also noticed a few neat extras that weren't in the PS2 version of Rebirth: additional backgrounds for your in-game desktop which are really cool (I have one of the new ones set up right now, and I'm enjoying its look), and some minor costmetic changes to some features, such as the affection gauge for your party members being a heart now instead of just a stylized circle.

Voice acting in the game has been cleaned up a bit and is essentially the same as it was in volume 1, although there were a few points in the game where it did sound like the voice acting was obviously recorded, breaking immersion a bit (I'm talking about a slight echo that tells that they took the audio in a booth, for example).  Also, two of the tracks that you can unlock to play on your in-game desktop don't seem to work, so there are some minor audio bugs that need taking care of.  In addtion, sometimes you'll get awkward camera angles that I don't remember there being in the original PS2 games.  And I've only come across a couple of graphical glitches; they weren't game-breaking, thankfully, but they were rather obvious.

The voice acting itself is standard mid-2k anime VA: competent, but hammy at times.  From what I've seen of footage of vol. 4, that has changed, but I'm expecting volumes 1 through 3 to be the same.  Not that there's anything necessarily wrong with that: some of the ham has its charm and adds to the game, though for some players it might be off-putting, since voice acting in games and anime have improved drastically since 2006-2008.

Yes, there are achievements for this game, and if you've 100%ed the PS2 games, you'll likely get most, if not all, of the achievements here.  But for those who haven't played the original PS2 versions, you'll likely find most of the achievements fairly easy to obtain with some effort.  It helps that there are in-game material rewards for doing actions and sidequests that you'd unlock the achievements for, anyway.

Overall, as far as I've played thus far, this is a solid remaster, and I'd recommend it to anyone seeking a JRPG series that isn't Final Fantasy, Kingdom Hearts, Tales, or Persona (or who has already played those series extensively and want more).  The story overall is at least passable, and there are genuine moments where you'll be really invested in the game's narrative.  The strong point of the .hack//G.U. series isn't its plot: its how the characters deal with the problems that they face, how they come into conflict with each other as the narrative and story progresses, and how they overcome those conflicts.  There's a bit of deus ex machina, but it's at acceptable anime-esqe levels.  You also have voice acting from a number of notable English VAs who have done a lot of other work in anime and video games: Johnny Yong Bosch, Liam O'brien, Yuri Lowental, Steven Blum, and Erin Fitzgerald are just a few of the famous names to be found, and their performances are well-executed.

I'll add more about volumes 3 and 4, as well as Parody Mode, when I get to them.

One final aside.  I'm personally hoping this remaster is financially successful for Bandai Namco, both on the PC and PS4.  Not just because I'm a fan of the .hack series and I want to see more of the franchise (potentially come over to the West), but also because I'm hoping that this game's success will lead to Bandai Namco doing an HD remaster of another cult-hit JRPG trilogy that I adore: Xenosaga episodes 1, 2, and 3.

Make it happen, Bandai Namco, and I will pay all the money I can get to have KOS-MOS in 1080 on my PC.  MAKE.  IT.  HAPPEN.

36433634.review:
Honestly I would have to say this is a game that I would buy over and over. Spent over  100+ hours on the PS2 varients and when I heard of this being released I just had to get this.

To make the game easier I would personally suggest getting a party together and going in boss areas 4 or 5 levels above your current... once you are past lvl 10 that is. To get to max level per game it will take anywhere between 5 to 7 hours depending on how fast you want to take it.   If you want to take the game in a story telling path, I would suggest on leveling to max then doing the story. If you want to keep it somewhat challenging then level up while you are doing the story.  

That being my 2 cents about levels and story...

I will admit, controls from PS2 bring brought to pc was a bit odd but once I learned the pc controls (keyboard) all battles suprisingly went much smoother and rather faster than I remember them going in the past days.  (Keyboard controls will be at bottom of review for those who need it or haven't figured it out as of current.)

Well, as a person that played all 3 past versions of the game(s)  (*PS2 versions*), I got this game about 5 days ago and beat all 4 (Rebirth, Reminisce, Redemption, and Reconnection) in 4 dsays.
Rebirth - 1 sitting (13 hours)
Reminisce - 1 sitting (14 hours)
Redemption - 2 sitting (13 hours | 5 hours)
Reconnection - 1 sitting (5 hours)
(estimated times per game)
{time above is far smaller than I would like because I didn't spend time hunting the doppleganger down over and over...}

|| Keyboard controls for those who need it ||
LT - control
RT - space
LB - C
RB - F

w, a, s, d - movement

||camera controls||
k - left
o - up 
l - down
; - right

|combat| 
F - skill trigger
A - enter
B - backspace
Y - E 
X - Q

|Function keys| 
Start - Escape
Select - Z
