TL;DR - Horrible port, stay far away from it. 

All in all a shitty port. If you want improvements show the devs this is unacceptable with your wallet by refunding or not buying.

System Specs:

Ram: 32GB
Graphics: 1080 Ti
CPU: AMD RYZEN 7 1700 3.0GHz
MOBO: ASRock AB350
HDD: SSD

ISSUE 1 - KEY MAPPING

The default key mapping for the game is for the Xbox. Yes, the Xbox. A system that none of the games were ever ported to or were ever developed for. This is like... Trying to but forklift controlls on a car... 

-Game will not accept/let me map buttons to a PS3/PS4 controller
-Game will not let me map buttons to a Logitech G13, Logitech F710 or a Razer Tartarus Chroma
-Game displays "Press (Y)" (This is for an xbox controller) even after the controls were remapped to different keyboard keys.
-Game displays non functional on screen prompts
-Game becomes unplayable for certain parts due to on screen prompts being incorrect for things like Trapped Chests




ISSUE 2 - Emulation Problems

The game is run inside of an emulator on your PC. So, this isn't even a real port. It's a game wrapped in an emulator.

-Game runs insanely fast or slow at certain points and becomes non functional due to certain things being tied to frame rate.
(This is a common problem with emulation)

-Due to framerate issues certain interactions become non responsive. Again, due to being emulated, certain things are tied to frame rate. (If you do not understand the HOW & WHY of this then google will help)




ISSUE 3 - Screen Tearing and other issues related to having large, high end or modern monitors

-Massive Screen tearing at 4k (Options do not help)
-Minor screen tearing at higher res above standard user market res




ISSUE 4 - AUDIO

-Character voices silent (Can sometimes be fixed by adjusting the audio settings But some times those settings don't save even when running the game as admin).

-Effect audio silent (Same as above)

36255850.review: I'm finally back into The World

36255817.review:
[h1]The wonderful trilogy is back after ten years.. and in four parts.[/h1]
The .hack//G.U. games were originally released on PlayStation 2 over ten years ago – Volume 1: Rebirth in 2006, Volume 2: Reminisce in 2007 and Volume 3: Redemption later the same year.

---------

 I played them all back then and what I remember is a splendid tale of hunt for revenge and difficult, as well as surprising, friendships and dedication. While the graphics back then weren’t the most impressive (especially from today’s perspective), [u]the game had (or, well.. has!) great cutscenes the players could always return to through in-game cutscenes viewer[/u]. Now both of those are here in high quality! 

[u].hack//G.U. takes place in a Massively Multiplayer Online Role-Playing Game played in virtual reality – “The World”. The player takes control of Haseo, an infamous Player Killer Killer known better by the nickname “The Terror of Death” who is on his search for a character who defeated his dear friend Shino in-game and ended up putting her in coma in real life. A forum fairytale. Tri-Edge.

Having defeated a hundred PKers who stood against him, he reaches level 133 in game and is powerful enough to take on Tri-Edge. [spoiler]However, there is more to him – a mysterious computer anomaly AIDA has began appearing inside the world of.. The World and its infections drive people mad with and for power, before draining them of life and putting them in an oh so familiar to Haseo comatose state.[/spoiler][/u]

The game was released with an anime called .hack//Roots, which puts some background story into the game – Haseo’s beginnings inside The World, his first guild “Twilight Brigade” and friends like the beloved Shino and mysterious patron Ovan, as well as his rise to becoming the Terror of Death. While useful and pretty interesting, it is not a requirement to watch it prior to playing G.U.

Aside from Roots, the .hack universe features a lot of other games (G.U. not being the first in the franchise!), animes, novels and even a CGI movie – a recreation of all three .hack games.

I keep mentioning three games, so why did I originally mention four parts? Well, [u]Last Recode ships with a brand new part to the trilogy – Volume 4: Reconnection[/u], which takes place after the end of the game and concerns.. a certain individual. No spoilers. You’ll know who in time~
Aside from Volume 4, there is also a Parody Mode and Terminal Disk - a collection of recordings from a CC Corp programmer who tells the story of the four games that came before G.U. as well as information about the lore on-goings inside the new game world.

---

 [b]G.U. is an action RPG with real-time combat taking place in round arenas[/b] – the players have their basic attack and block functions as well as a list of skill triggers to use at all times. If used at the right time, players may unleash Rengeki – a boost to damage delivered during a skill trigger and party morale. The game also features a different kind of combat with more shoot ‘em up elements. As it is an RPG, there are plenty of items for Haseo and his party to use – from items and weapons to spells. Haseo is a class called the Adept Rogue, so [u]he is able to switch between a few different weapon – his weapons of choice are Twin Blades, a (chainsaw) Broadsword and a Scythe.[/u]

Aside from the aforementioned elements, there is a world outside of the World – though not outside of the computer. [u]You are able to log out of the game and access your e-mail, news site articles & videos, web forums, browse fan art of in-game things or play a card minigame! This is also the menu where you access the cutscenes you have unlocked so far. It might seem minor, but it’s a really cool and immersive thing to log out and browse through messages about how badass the last Arena fight was or how they heard rumours about various events – it truly makes the world feel alive.[/u]

---

[b]Performance?[/b] I have a rather [u]mediocre laptop with a GeForce 940MX, Intel Core i5-7200U, 8GBs of RAM and a really terrible HDD[/u] - so bad the entire computer can freeze up when downloading things. [u]I can play the game pretty fine with 30-50FPS without any sudden major drops.
 However, some parts of the games are a bit choppy[/u] - animations seem to scale with FPS, so the lower it is the slower Haseo will run, or the more out of sync the audio will be during cutscene close-ups (not the main CGI cutscenes, but little animations that sometimes appear in various convos, usually include lipsync). As the computer I'm using is not the best (940MX being more or less the equivalent of GTX 740, I believe?), the above might be better on other machines.

--

One shameful thing is that the [b]graphical upgrade wasn't as thorough as it could be[/b]. At some points the game just looks weird because of the lower quality models, faces don't move most of the time outside of cutscenes - in fact, more effort seems to have been spent on upgrading those rather than the actual game bits themselves. Also there's a bunch of clipping here and there.

---

[b]Big plus for the game’s soundtrack – a definite strong part of the series![/b] Some of my favourite pieces are Gentle Hands (existing both in [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QJwy-Fi1NT8]Japanese[/url] and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rHcrj_44Hq4]English![/url]), [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lG47XOiNlKQ]Terror of Death[/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0MW8IHfhuLA]Everything in These Hands[/url] and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mD2dnwgpYCA]Serpent of Lore[/url].

---------

There might be bits of nostalgia behind my words, but considering through those ten years I regularly returned to the .hack Wiki and cutscenes uploaded to YouTube as well as replayed the game a few times using emulators, I think [b]I can bravely say .hack//G.U. is a wonderful game one should look into [/b] – especially if you’re already interested in anime or Japanese RPGs, as those will only help you get into it.


[h1][b][u]TL;DR - A story definitely worth experiencing, but the port isn't the greatest. 
Still worth it, in my opinion.[/u][/b][/h1]

36254946.review:
Весьма качественный Remastered старой серии игр с PS2.
Добавили 4-ую главу, подправилили текстурки, а так же переделали ролики на честный HD.

Серия [u].hack[/u] повествует об онлайн игре The World, в которую и засел наш главный герой.
Будучи озлобленным на PK игроков, Хасео стал выискивать их и нещадно уничтожать, за что получил прозвище "The Terror of Death".
Конечно, без девушки тут не обошлось, в онлайн игре её убили, да так, что она впала в кому в реальной жизни (И это всё задолго до Sword Art Online).
Герою повезло чуть больше, его персонаж был сброшен (привет 1 лвл), и теперь ему предстоит пройти весь путь с нуля, после чего предпринять вторую попытку отомстить.

И так, геймплей делится на 2 части: зaдротство в онлайн игре, что включает бои, путешествия и диалоги, вторая же часть посвящена изучению новостей, форумов игры, а так же общению через электронную почту. Уже наткнулся на пару забавных видео, включая репортаж Онлайн Джека. Возможно, что-то будет происходить и в реальном мире. Сам серией знаком плохо.

Игравшие в какие-либо ММО будут отлично ориентироваться в местном сленге, проблемах нубов и т.д.

Графончик средненький, в итоге вышли на уровень ранних проектов с PS3. 
Понятное дело, что тормозить тут точно нечему, так что с оптимизацией проблем нет и быть не может.
Все диалоги озвучены, что несомненно идёт в плюс, ибо разговаривают тут весьма много.

Стандартная рекомендация: фанаты jRPG оценят.

36251903.review:
Como é bom estar de volta. O G.U é minha saga de jogos preferida então não ficarei jogando purpurina sobre ele haha. O que posso dizer:

- Port Perfeito, não tive absolutamente nenhuma queda de frame até o momento, realmente me senti em casa.
- Remaster das cutscenes está muito bem feito.
- Vários Save Slots exatamente como no PS2, perfeito para quem quer zerar o jogo diversas vezes.

Única coisa que senti falta foi a frase antes da apresentação inicial. No caso do primeiro volume a tela "Do you know Tri-Edge?". Você pode acessar os volumes separadamente através do menu inicial, mas eles te jogam direto no menu do jogo pulando as apresentações iniciais, realmente ficou um pouco mais prático mas senti falta daquela nostalgia em assistir as apresentações antes como no PS2 (apesar delas ainda poderem ser assistidas no PC do jogo).

Se você nunca jogou o jogo:
- Tem uma ótima história, cheia de viradas.
- Você se apega/odeia muito os personagens pois eles são muito bem trabalhados
- Combate muito bom, mas tenha em mente que ele tem no mínimo 10 anos de idade (contando do Volume 3) então não espere nada inovador.
- Terá no mínimo 20h de gameplay em cada volume (posso falar até o volume 3 já que o 4 é novo) sem nem chegar perto do 100%, então a questão do preço/tempo de jogo vale MUITO a pena.
- Pode passar todo o progresso de um Volume pro outro.
- Se está preocupado pelo G.U ser a segunda série da saga .hack não se preocupe, tem um terminal disc que explica a história dos 4 volumes que precedem o G.U mas que eu recomendo muito QUE NÃO VEJA ATÉ ZERAR O VOL.3. Isso irá ajudar MUITO no suspense do jogo, acredite eu começei pelo G.U e não me arrependo por nem um segundo.

Ótimo jogo + ótimo port + nostalgia = 100/10

36250133.review:
"I told people online about my problems. In real life, no one would care about them, but online, everyone cares. My online friends are all so nice. They worry about me, they give me advice. I just wish real life was like my life online." -Quote from an article in the game DAMN.

This is perfect if you're a fan or a new player wanting to play this franchise (ps2 copies are rare and expensive). I never had the chance to play vol 2 and 3 because of the price years after it went rare. I had beaten vol 1 a few times back on the ps2 years ago. When this release was first announced I was nothing but excited to get my money's worth. 

The quality of the game feels really good and smooth. The combat is pretty straightforward and simple with a one button attack but you get additional skills to execute. Additionally, you also have recovery attacks for more strategy if I may say so. It doesn't sound fun from words alone but it is when you have your hands in control of the game. Gameplay allows you to do general things you'd expect from an actual mmo like guild management, arena, improve gears questing etc.. The game isn't complex by any means. It's straightforward fun as a game should be.

.Hack GU has a great narrative that give reason to invest time in the game. There is more than enough cutscenes to entertain the story and develop the characters. Furthermore, the fictional forums the game provides in its internet sphere offers branching narratives and lore to the world of .Hack in game and the real world. The game was ahead of its time tackling issues relevant today about technology when it becomes too much a part of our lives not just for a solution but more so for convenience (which you would have to read in the in game forum). It also makes you feel like you are in a forum with people discussing these topics like in real people. But even if you don't read them, the narrative will allude to these things or some characters will mention them.

There are some minor pop in issues in open fields which can be annoying as well as the LOD for distance in the outside maps. It is less of an issue in closed areas. The graphical quality is a decent improvement.
